revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox musical artist | image = Jordanaandmccollaboratortechnorganic.jpg | caption = Jordana at Technorganic Records showcase party with MC Collaborator | name = Jordana LeSesne | genre = [[Drum and bass]] | occupation = Producer, musician, DJ | birth_place = [[Pittsburgh]], Pennsylvania, US | years_active = 1995–present | website = {{URL|www.jordanamusic.com}} | background=non_performing_personnel }}
'''1.8.7''' is a pseudonym for '''Jordana LeSesne''', a musician and producer from [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vh1.com/artists/az/1_8_7/bio.jhtml |title=VH1 Biography |publisher=Vh1.com |date= |accessdate=2010-09-08 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wV2840oQ?url=http://www.vh1.com/artists/az/1_8_7/bio.jhtml |archivedate=February 14, 2011 |deadurl=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref> She became widely known in the mid-1990s as an American [[Drum and Bass]] producer. The Village Voice described her as being "[w]idely regarded as the top U.S. drum'n'bass producer."<ref name="villagevoice2000">[http://www.villagevoice.com/2000-02-29/music/music/ Top Jungle Producer Attacked] Tuesday, February 29, 2000 Village Voice {{webarchive |url=https://www.webcitation.org/5wV28QgD0?url=http://www.villagevoice.com/2000-02-29/music/music/ |date=February 14, 2011 }}</ref> Vibe magazine called her "one of the most respected Drum ‘n' Bass producers in the US."<ref name="Group1999">{{cite book|author=Vibe Media Group|title=Vibe|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZCgEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA38|date=February 1999|publisher=Vibe Media Group|pages=38–|issn=1070-4701}}</ref> In 2015 Jordana was named as one of "20 Women Who Shaped the History of Dance Music" by the authoritative dance music magazine Mixmag.<ref name="MyUser_Mixmag.net_December_21_2015c">{{cite web |url=http://www.mixmag.net/feature/20-women-who-shaped-the-history-of-dance-music/61 |title=- - Mixmag |newspaper=Mixmag.net |date= |author= |accessdate= December 21, 2015}}</ref> Previously, in 2014, For Harriet Magazine named Jordana as one of "12 Women in Black Music History You Should Know".<ref name="MyUser_Forharriet.com_December_21_2015c">{{cite web |url=http://www.forharriet.com/2014/06/12-women-in-black-music-history-you.html#axzz3v00dLDWf |title=12 Women in Black Music History You Should Know |newspaper=Forharriet.com |date= |author= |accessdate= December 21, 2015}}</ref> In 2014, Complex Magazine UK named one of her songs to a list of "36 Great American Drum & Bass Tracks".<ref name="MyUser_Com_December_21_2015c">{{cite web |url=http://www.complex.com/music/2014/07/american-drum-bass-tracks/1-8-7-we-are-not-alone |title=1.8.7 - "We Are Not Alone" - 36 Great American Drum & Bass Tracks |newspaper=Com |date= |author= |accessdate= December 21, 2015}}</ref> She is [[transgender]] and has been living as a woman since 1998.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Roll With the Changes|url = http://citypaper.net/articles/101598/music.jordana.shtml?print=1|archive-url = https://archive.is/20120707172926/http://citypaper.net/articles/101598/music.jordana.shtml?print=1|dead-url = yes|archive-date = 2012-07-07|website = citypaper.net|access-date = 2016-01-19}}</ref>
She has released of over 50 tracks which includes four full-length albums, several EPs, and many remixes under the alias "1.8.7". The album ''When Worlds Collide'', released in 1997, became known for its "dark pummeling assaults". She has also licensed tracks for numerous compilations as well as the [[Sci Fi Channel (United States)|Sci Fi Channel]]. Three of her albums charted in the Top 25 of both the CMJ (College Music Journal) and Mixmag U.S. (later Mixer Magazine, now defunct) for 1997 as well as 1998<ref name="Inc.1998.2">{{cite book|author=CMJ Network, Inc.|title=CMJ New Music Monthly|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fCoEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA78|date=December 1998|publisher=CMJ Network, Inc.|pages=78–|issn=1074-6978}}</ref><ref name="Inc.1998.2"/> and 1999. Her third album "The Cities Collection" debuted in the CMJ Top 5 climbed to the #2 position on CMJ Music Monthly's dance chart for June 2000.<ref name="Inc.2000.1">{{cite book|author=CMJ Network, Inc.|title=CMJ New Music Monthly|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IyoEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA48|date=March 2000|publisher=CMJ Network, Inc.|pages=48–|issn=1074-6978}}</ref><ref name="Inc.2000.2">{{cite book|author=CMJ Network, Inc.|title=CMJ New Music Report|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=r7_Z2ZPWygkC&pg=PA27|date=13 March 2000|publisher=CMJ Network, Inc.|pages=27–|issn=0890-0795}}</ref><ref name="Inc.2000.3">{{cite book|author=CMJ Network, Inc.|title=CMJ New Music Monthly|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kCoEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA82|date=June 2000|publisher=CMJ Network, Inc.|pages=82–|issn=1074-6978}}</ref>
Her works have been reviewed by the likes of ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'',<ref name="Inc.2000">{{cite book|author=CMJ Network, Inc.|title=CMJ New Music Monthly|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kCoEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA82|date=June 2000|publisher=CMJ Network, Inc.|page=95|issn=1074-6978}}</ref> ''[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]]'', ''[[Rolling Stone]]'', ''Urb'', ''Mixer'', ''[[Mixmag]]'', ''[[Raygun Magazine|Raygun]]'', ''Vibe'',<ref name="Group1999"/> and Trip (Español),<ref name="SA2000">{{cite book|author=Trip Editora e Propaganda SA|title=Trip|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ni0EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PT85|date=February 2000|publisher=Trip Editora e Propaganda SA|pages=85–|issn=1414-350X}}</ref> as well as ''Knowledge'' – the U.K. Drum and Bass magazine. In 1999 she was listed in Raygun's "Who's Who of International DJs". She was one of the headlining DJs on Knowledge Magazine's 28 city ''"Kung Fu Knowledge"'' tour in 1999.<ref>{{cite web|title=Kung Fu Knowledge Tour Cities |url=http://www.bmotion.com/kungfu_rave/map_cities.htm |work=Bmotion |accessdate=October 3, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131004234254/http://www.bmotion.com/kungfu_rave/map_cities.htm |archivedate=October 4, 2013 }}</ref> She also made ''[[Out Magazine]]'s'' OUT100 for the year 2000.<ref>{{cite journal|title=none|journal=Out Magazine|issue=74|pages=45|date=January 2000}}</ref>
==Impact on Music==
Jordana's work has influenced other artists such as well known [[dubstep]] producer [[Bassnectar]] who heavily sampled ''5 A.M. Rinse (feat. MC Sphinx)'', the last song on her first album ''When Worlds Collide'' for his song ''Here We Go'' off of his 2010 EP and single ''[[Timestretch (album)|Timestretch]]''.<ref>{{cite web|author=iphoneunclockseattle|title=Bassnectar's Here We Go sample of 1.8.7 feat. MC Sphinx's 5 A.M. Rinse|url=http://www.whosampled.com/sample/103220/Bassnectar-Here-We-Go-1.8.7-MC-Sphinx-5-A.M.-Rinse/|work=WhoSampled|accessdate=November 2, 2013}}</ref> Additionally, [[electronic rock]] act [[Celldweller]] sampled "Wake Up" off of her first album as well as "San Francisco" off of her third album "The Cities Collection" in their 2013 song "Uncrowned".<ref>{{cite web|author=jordana|title=Celldweller samples Wake Up and San Francisco|url=https://www.facebook.com/JordanaDnB/posts/10152845170979815|work=WhoSampled|accessdate=May 9, 2014}}</ref>
In 1999 Drum & Bass/Hip Hop producer and label owner Hive approached Jordana to remix her song ''Defcon-1'' also off of ''When Worlds Collide''. Hive's remix appears on his 2001 album ''The Raw Uncut''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hive – The Raw Uncut EP|url=http://www.discogs.com/Hive-The-Raw-Uncut-EP/release/70304|work=Discogs|accessdate=November 2, 2013}}</ref> Jordana collaborated with [[Lady Sovereign]] on a song early in Sov's career after the two met through an internet chat room for StrikeFM.co.uk, an online radio station which Jordana had a show, and the now defunct UKGargageWorldwide.com forums. The two would later team up when Jordana under her Lady J alias, had Lady Sovereign MC for her radio show on Flex 103.6FM London.<ref name="MyUser_Https:_December_21_2015c">{{cite web|url=http://www.flexfm.net/site/index.php |title=: : Welcome to the FLEX FM NETWORK - Home of FLEX 103.6 FM - LONDON : : |newspaper=Https: |date= |author= |accessdate=December 21, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20020601214235/http://www.flexfm.net/site/index.php |archivedate=June 1, 2002 }}</ref>
New Zealand based Dubstep and Drum & Bass producer Alexis K/Unsub has also cited Jordana as an influence and the two are collaborating on music and a possible tour.
==History==
Jordana first came to the attention of the music industry when she was asked to remix Blondie's "Atomic." Her "Beautiful Drum & Bass Remix" appeared along with Armand Van Helden and Diddy's remixes on the single.<ref name="Group1999"/> A little over a year following that release Mac McFarlane, the promoter of the well established and legendary New York City Drum'n'Bass club night, Konkrete Jungle, contacted Jordana to create a Konkrete Jungle themed song for a CD compilation/mix-CD. Jordana created the song "Konkrete Jungle" for that purpose. Described by CMJ as containing "menacing hardstep attacks"<ref name="Inc.1998">{{cite book|author=CMJ Network, Inc.|title=CMJ New Music Monthly|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-ikEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA62|date=October 1998|publisher=CMJ Network, Inc.|pages=62–|issn=1074-6978}}</ref> it was released on the Ultra Records compilation, "Konkrete Jungle - Maximum Drum & Bass," mixed by BBC Radio 1 Drum'n'Bass show regular host Jumping Jack Frost. Following extensive touring throughout North America and abroad as a live Drum & Bass artist, Liquid Sky Music, an indie label distributed by Caroline Distribution signed her to a three-album contract in late 1996.
==Hate Crime in Ohio==
On the night of February 22, 2000 in Kent, Ohio Jordana was attacked and brutally beaten in a transphobic hate crime by a group of men including Matthew Gostlin of Akron, Ohio.<ref name="Maximum Rocknroll">{{cite book|title=Maximum Rocknroll|url=https://books.google.com/?id=SHVbAAAAMAAJ&q=%221.8.7%22+bass&dq=%221.8.7%22+bass|year=2000|publisher=Maximum Rock 'n' Roll}}</ref> Gostlin and other assailants jumped her in the parking lot outside of "The Robin Hood" nightclub where she had just performed on the Cities Collection tour. The attack took place while she was escorted from the event with the event promoter to the promoters car. The group of men attacked suddenly and Jordana lost consciousness almost immediately after being struck in the face. She suffered nerve damage to the lower part of her face from her lower lip down as a result. She was quoted as saying in the May issue of CMJ New Music Monthly that in the seconds just prior to the attack: "I saw his face. I remember the look on his face. It was this look of utter hate, like 'I'm going to kill you.'"<ref name="Inc.2000.4">{{cite book|author=CMJ Network, Inc.|title=CMJ New Music Monthly|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GioEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA13|date=May 2000|publisher=CMJ Network, Inc.|pages=13|issn=1074-6978}}</ref> George Meesig of Cleveland, Ohio shoved one of the men away and helped Jordana.<ref name="MyUser_Villagevoice.com_December_21_2015c.1">{{cite web |url=http://www.villagevoice.com/music/music-6395337 |title=Music |newspaper=Villagevoice.com |date= |author= |accessdate= December 21, 2015}}</ref> In an interview with the Village Voice following the attack, Meesig stated that Gostlin had "misgendered" her.{{Citation needed|date=January 2016}} Other reports from people on the message board for Breakbeat Science (a NYC based Drum'n'Bass record store) mentioned transphobic slurs being shouted during the attack.<ref name="MyUser_Villagevoice.com_December_21_2015c.1"/> Jordana subsequently cancelled the tour to recover.<ref name="Maximum Rocknroll"/> Gostlin, while charged, was never arrested nor spent any time in court. Jordana's family was told by the Portage County (Ohio) prosecutor's office that attempts had been made to serve the warrant but Gostlin's whereabouts were unknown. As a result of no movement on the case by the authorities, Jordana felt that justice would not be served. They{{clarify|reason=Who is "they"?|date=June 2016}} left the U.S. for England because of their concerns about personal safety and well-being.
==Additional Work in Music Industry==
In addition to production Jordana has also been a DJ, musician and singer. In 2001–2002 Jordana worked at Flex FM in London, England as Lady J with [[Lady Sovereign]] MCing for her during Jordana's radio show.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.ukmusic.com/forum/chit-chat/lock-in-to-flex-fm-2nite-10911.html|title = Lock in to FLex FM 2nite|last = Sovereign|first = Lady|date = May 18, 2002|work = ukmusic.com/|accessdate = May 30, 2013|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20140810062924/http://www.ukmusic.com/forum/chit-chat/lock-in-to-flex-fm-2nite-10911.html|archive-date = August 10, 2014|dead-url = yes|df = mdy-all}}</ref> In 2002 she held a club residency spinning [[UK Garage]], [[2-Step Garage]] and [[House Music]] at legendary club night Trinity in London's Vauxhall neighborhood.
After returning to the US, Jordana has returned to her rock roots and fronts a melodic goth metal band in Seattle. Just prior to that she was asked to play bass in another band briefly where she met and became close friends with singer/songwriter Sheltia Burke.
Currently, Jordana is scoring the documentary, ''Free CeCe,'' produced and directed by Jacqueline Gares and actress/director [[Laverne Cox]] of the series [[Orange Is The New Black]]. The documentary details the struggles of [[CeCe McDonald]], an African-American transwoman who was wrongfully incarcerated for murder for defending herself against a hate driven attack on her life outside of a bar in Minneapolis.<ref name="MyUser_Https:_December_21_2015c.2">{{cite web |url=https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/free-cece-post-production-campaign#/updates |title=FREE CeCe! Post-Production Campaign |newspaper=Https: |date= |author= |accessdate= December 21, 2015}}</ref>
Jordana is working on a new Drum and Bass E.P. for Bristol, UK based Complex Records. Her guitar and vocal work have featured on clips of songs off of her new E.P. posted to Soundcloud and on cover songs she has posted on AfroPunk.com.<ref name="MyUser_Afropunk.com_December_21_2015c">{{cite web |url=http://www.afropunk.com/music/playlist/popup?playlistUrl=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.afropunk.com%2Fmusic%2Fplaylist%2Fshow%3Ffmt%3Dxspf%26id%3D2059274%253APlaylist%253A848159%26mdate%3D2015-11-17T00%253A12%253A52.127Z%26nik%3D0hal9p4m47ehw&playlistType=user |title=AFROPUNK |newspaper=Afropunk.com |date= |author= |accessdate=December 21, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151222145454/http://www.afropunk.com/music/playlist/popup?playlistUrl=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.afropunk.com%2Fmusic%2Fplaylist%2Fshow%3Ffmt%3Dxspf%26id%3D2059274%253APlaylist%253A848159%26mdate%3D2015-11-17T00%253A12%253A52.127Z%26nik%3D0hal9p4m47ehw&playlistType=user# |archive-date=December 22, 2015 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
==Literary Mentions==
Jordana has been featured in several books. Her success rising from the depressed 80s economy of a "rust belt" city to MTV featured electronica artist garnered a mention in 2002 New York Times bestseller "[[The Rise of the Creative Class]]" by economist [[Richard Florida]]. She appears in two books examining the history and rise of the American rave/EDM scene: Michaelangelo Matos's ''The Underground is Massive''<ref>{{cite book |last=Matos |first1=Michaelangelo |title=The Underground Is Massive: How Electronic Dance Music Conquered America |publisher=Dey Street Books |date=April 28, 2015 |page=154 |isbn=978-0062271785 }}</ref> details an early online exchange between her and Moby dealing with the role of live performance in a rave context. She is also mentioned in ''Rave Culture: An Insider's Overview'' by Jimi Fritz and Virginia Smallfry.<ref name="Fritz1999">{{cite book|author=Jimi Fritz|title=Rave Culture: An Insider's Overview|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CiW3aOptLW4C|year=1999|publisher=SmallFry Press|isbn=978-0-9685721-0-8|page=162}}</ref>
==Personal life==
An extensive interview with Jordana was also featured in "The New Transsexuals" a book by rock journalist and illustrator George Petros(Thrasher, Seconds, Propaganda, EXIT magazines) published in 2012.<ref>{{cite book |last=Petros |first1=George |author-link1=George Petros |url=http://georgepetros.com/books/tnt.php#.VniT8hUrJhF |title=The New Transsexuals: The Next Step In Human Evolution |editor-last=Lehman |editor-first=Deanna |publisher=Creation Books |year=2012 |pages=247–274 |isbn=978-0-9855018-1-5 |accessdate=2015-12-22 }}</ref>
She currently resides in [[Seattle]].

==Filmography==
In 2002 Jordana licensed "One vocal, background use, forty-five seconds (0:45) in length" from her song "Break In" to [[Paramount Pictures]] for the [[Zoolander]] DVD release.

{{Infobox musical artist | name = 1788-L | background = temporary | image = | birth_name = | birth_date = | genre = {{hlist|[[Electronic music|Electronic]]|[[new beat]]}} | occupation = {{hlist|[[Record producer]]|[[Disc jockey|DJ]]|[[musician]]}} | instrument = [[Digital audio workstation]] | origin = | years_active = 2018–present | label = Deadbeats | associated_acts = {{hlist|[[Illenium]]|[[Said The Sky]]|[[Rezz]]|4AM|Blanke}} | website = {{URL|1788-L.com}} }} '''1788-L''' is an [[electronic music]] producer.{{cite web|author=Meadow, Matthew|title=1788-L Is Already Getting Lots Of Hype After Only Three Tracks|work=YourEDM|url=http://www.youredm.com/2018/02/23/1788-l-already-getting-lots-hype-three-tracks/|accessdate=26 March 2018}}{{cite web|title=1788-L Drops One Of The Most Insane Daft Punk Remixes We Have Ever Heard|work=EDMSauce|url=https://www.edmsauce.com/2018/03/02/1788-l-drops-one-insane-daft-punk-remixes-ever-heard/|accessdate=27 March 2018}}{{cite web|title=Dexter's Beat Laboratory Vol. 32|work=Dancing Astronaut|url=http://www.dancingastronaut.com/2018/03/dexters-beat-laboratory-vol-32/|accessdate=27 March 2018}} They rose to fame in 2018 with a remix of [[Porter Robinson|Virtual Self]]'s "Particle Arts" uploaded onto their [[SoundCloud]] account.{{cite web|title=Virtual Self- Particle Arts ( 1 7 8 8 – L / F L I P )|work=EDMSauce|url=https://www.edmsauce.com/2018/02/13/virtual-self-particle-arts-1788-l/|accessdate=27 March 2018}} Other releases following this include "Multiverse" (with 4AM) and a remix of [[Daft Punk]]'s "Rinzler".{{cite web|author=Evanson, Austin|title=Premiere: Daft Punk – Rinzler (1788-L Remix)|work=[[Dancing Astronaut]]|url=http://www.dancingastronaut.com/2018/03/premiere-daft-punk-rinzler-1788-l-remix/|accessdate=27 March 2018}} ==Career== On 26 January 2018, 1788-L uploaded their debut release, "Replica", on [[SoundCloud]].{{cite web|title=R E P L I C A by 1788-L|work=[[SoundCloud]]|url=https://soundcloud.com/1788-l/replica-22|accessdate=27 March 2018}} A [[music download|digital download]] release of they song was issued on 2 February 2018.{{cite web|author=1788-L|title=Replica - Single|work=[[iTunes Store]]|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/replica-single/1342467838|accessdate=27 March 2018}} On 9 February 2018 they released a remix of "Particle Arts" by [[Porter Robinson|Virtual Self]]. On 2 March 2018, a remix of [[Daft Punk]]'s "Rinzler" (from ''[[Tron: Legacy (soundtrack)|Tron: Legacy]]'') was released, and premiered on [[Dancing Astronaut]].{{cite web|title=Premiere: Daft Punk – Rinzler (1788-L Remix)|work=Dancing Astronaut|url=https://dancingastronaut.com/2018/03/premiere-daft-punk-rinzler-1788-l-remix/|accessdate=27 March 2018}} On 30 March 2018, a remix of "[[Radioactivity (song)|Radioactivity]]" by [[Kraftwerk]] was released.{{cite web|title=1788-L Drops Newest Track, A Remix Of Kraftwerk’s “Radioactivity”|work=YourEDM|url=https://www.youredm.com/2018/03/30/1788-l-drops-newest-track-a-remix-of-kraftwerks-radioactivity/|accessdate=3 April 2018}}{{cite web|title=1788-L Drops A Fire Remix of a Kraftwerk Classic|work=EDMSauce|url=https://www.edmsauce.com/2018/03/30/1788-l-drops-a-fire-remix-of-a-kraftwerk-classic/|accessdate=3 April 2018}} His debut extended play, ''[[Sentience (EP)|Sentience]]'', which comprises four tracks was released on August 24, 2018 through [[Zeds Dead]]' label, Deadbeats. 1788-L performed their first live show on July 7, 2018 in [[Los Angeles, California]].{{Cite web |url=https://www.youredm.com/2018/07/08/half-of-soundcloud-showed-up-to-1788-ls-crazy-debut-in-la-last-night/ |title=Half of Soundcloud Showed Up to 1788-L's Crazy Debut in LA Last Night |last=Meadow |first=Matthew |date=July 8, 2018 |website=Your EDM |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180708222226/https://www.youredm.com/2018/07/08/half-of-soundcloud-showed-up-to-1788-ls-crazy-debut-in-la-last-night/ |archive-date=July 8, 2018 |accessdate=August 25, 2018}} ==Discography== ===Extended plays=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! style="width:7em;"| Title ! style="width:15em;"| Details |- ! scope="row"| ''[[Sentience (EP)|Sentience]]''{{Cite web |url=https://dancingastronaut.com/2018/08/1788-ls-destructive-debut-ep-s-e-n-t-e-n-c-e-finally-arrived/ |title=1788-L’s destructive debut EP, ‘S E N T I E N C E,’ has finally arrived |last=Norris |first=Asher |date=24 August 2018 |website=[[Dancing Astronaut]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180825021038/https://dancingastronaut.com/2018/08/1788-ls-destructive-debut-ep-s-e-n-t-e-n-c-e-finally-arrived/ |archive-date=25 August 2018 |accessdate=25 August 2018}} | * Released: 24 August 2018 * Label: Deadbeats * Format: [[Music download|Digital download]] |} ===Singles=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" ! {{pp-blp|expiry=22:40, 30 August 2019|small=yes}} {{Use mdy dates|date=May 2018}}{{Infobox musical artist | name = 21 Savage | image = 21 Savage 2018.jpg | caption = 21 Savage performing in Austin, Texas in June 2018. | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Shayaa Bin Abraham-Joseph | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1992|10|22|mf=yes}} | birth_place = [[Atlanta|Atlanta, Georgia]], U.S. | genre = {{flatlist| * [[Hip hop music|Hip hop]] * [[Trap music|trap]] * [[gangsta rap]] }} | occupation = {{flatlist| * Rapper * singer * songwriter * record producer }} | instrument = Vocals | years_active = {{start date|2014}}–present | label = {{flatlist| * Slaughter Gang * [[Epic Records|Epic]] }} | associated_acts = {{flatlist| * [[Metro Boomin]] * [[Offset (rapper)|Offset]] * [[Southside (record producer)|Southside]] * [[Sonny Digital]] * [[Zaytoven]] }} | website = {{URL|21savage.com}} }}
'''Shayaa Bin Abraham-Joseph''' (born October 22, 1992), better known by his stage name '''21 Savage''', is an American [[rapper]], record producer, and songwriter from [[Atlanta, Georgia]]. Abraham-Joseph grew up around criminality and eventually dropped out of school, beginning to rap in 2013 after the death of a friend. He gained attention in the [[Atlanta]] underground for the 2015 mixtape ''[[The Slaughter Tape]]'' before attaining nationwide attention following the [[Metro Boomin]] collaborative album ''[[Savage Mode]]'' (2016), its lead single "[[X (21 Savage and Metro Boomin song)|X]]", and his collaboration with Drake, "[[Sneakin']]".<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.interviewmagazine.com/music/21-savage-seth-rogen-interview|title=21 Savage chops it up with Seth Rogen|date=2018-04-26|work=Interview Magazine|access-date=2018-07-10|language=en-US}}</ref>
Abraham-Joseph released his debut studio album, ''[[Issa Album]]'', in 2017<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/rap-music/the-break/2015/10/the-break-presents-21-savage/|title=The Break Presents: 21 Savage|last=C.M.|first=Emmanuel|date=October 9, 2015|work=[[XXL (magazine)|XXL Magazine]]|accessdate=May 2, 2018}}</ref> which debuted at number two on the ''Billboard'' 200 and gave Abraham-Joseph his first top twenty song, "[[Bank Account (song)|Bank Account]]." He achieved his first number one single at the end of 2017 with his feature on [[Post Malone]]'s "[[Rockstar (Post Malone song)|Rockstar]]."<ref name="XXL Magazine2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2017/10/post-malone-21-savage-rockstar-no-1-billboard-hot-100-chart/|title=Post Malone's ''Rockstar'' Hits No. 1 on Billboard Hot 100 Chart|website=XXL Magazine|access-date=May 2, 2018}}</ref> In 2017, he also released the [[Offset (rapper)|Offset]] and Metro Boomin collaboration ''[[Without Warning (21 Savage, Offset and Metro Boomin album)|Without Warning]]''.
==Early life== Shayaa Bin Abraham-Joseph was born on October 22, 1992, in Atlanta, Georgia.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/21-savage-mn0003515232/biography|title=Biography & History|last=Jeffries|first=David|website=[[AllMusic]]|accessdate=February 22, 2018}}</ref><ref name="Birthplace2">{{cite web|url=https://schedule.sxsw.com/2016/events/event_MS37401|title=21 Savage|author=<!--Not stated-->|website=[[South by Southwest]]|access-date=May 2, 2018}}</ref> He was raised by his mother Heather, who is of [[People of Dominica|Dominica]] descent, and his four brothers and six sisters, though one is deceased due to a shooting after a [[Illegal drug trade|drug deal]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://djbooth.net/features/2016-11-22-brutal-story-behind-21-savage-dagger-face-tattoo|title=The Brutal Story Behind 21 Savage's Dagger Face Tattoo|last=James|first=Andy|date=November 22, 2018|website=[[DJBooth]]|access-date=May 2, 2018|quote=}}</ref>
In the seventh grade, Abraham-Joseph was banned permanently from every school in the [[DeKalb County School District]] due to gun possession.<ref>{{cite AV media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=v1CmVcwIyKo|title=21 Savage Interview With The Breakfast Club (8-4-16)|date=August 4, 2016|people=[[Charlamagne tha God]], [[DJ Envy]]|publisher=[[The Breakfast Club (radio show)]]|location=[[New York City]]|access-date=May 6, 2018|medium=Video}}</ref> This led him to begin attending schools around the [[Atlanta metropolitan area]] before being sent to a youth detention center.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.hotnewhiphop.com/everything-you-need-to-know-about-21-savage-news.22853.html|title=Everything You Need To Know About 21 Savage|work=HotNewHipHop|access-date=2017-08-24}}</ref> After being released from the youth detention center, he completed eighth grade through an alternative program before finishing a semester of high school, dropping out in his freshman year following multiple exclusions which Abraham-Joseph said he was "exhausted" by.<ref name=":02">{{Cite news|url=http://www.thefader.com/2016/08/04/21-savage-the-breakfast-club-interview|title=21 Savage Talks Being An "A" Student, Losing His Best Friends On The Breakfast Club|work=The FADER|access-date=2018-07-10|language=en}}</ref>
After dropping out, Abraham-Joseph joined a gang affiliated with the [[Bloods]]<ref name=":2" /> and became a full-time drug dealer, mainly selling cannabis.<ref name=":02" /> He also took parts in other criminal activities including robbery and grand theft auto regularly, though only being arrested once after contraband was found in a car he was driving.<ref name=":12">{{Cite news|url=https://www.gq.com/story/21-savage-profile-2018|title=21 Savage: From Robbin’ Season to Role Model|last=Wood|first=Samuel Hine, Geordie|date=2018-06-27|work=GQ|access-date=2018-07-10|language=en}}</ref> In 2011, when Abraham-Joseph was 19, he lost his "right hand" man, Larry in a shootout.<ref name=":02" /> In 2013, on his 21st birthday, Abraham-Joseph was shot six times and his brother Johnny "Tay-Man" was killed during an attempted robbery.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thefader.com/2015/10/01/feature-21-savage|title=Meet 21 Savage, Atlanta’s Most Respected New Rapper|website=[[The Fader]]|access-date=August 24, 2017}}</ref>
==Career== ===2014–15: Early releases=== Following the death of his friend in a shootout on his 21st birthday, Abraham-Joseph began rapping, naming himself after the event<ref name=":12" /> though Savage came from Instagram predictions.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.capitalxtra.com/features/facts/21-savage/|title=19 Facts You Need To Know About 'Rockstar' Rapper 21 Savage|work=Capital XTRA|access-date=2018-07-10|language=en}}</ref> His music career was originally subsidized by the uncle of his deceased friend, giving him money for studio time in 2013.<ref name=":2" /> On November 12, 2014, 21 Savage's debut single, "Picky", produced by DJ Plugg, was released. It was later included on his debut mixtape, ''[[The Slaughter Tape]]'', which was released on May 25, 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.livemixtapes.com/mixtapes/34127/21-savage-the-slaughter-tape.html|title=21 Savage - The Slaughter Tape|work=LiveMixtapes|accessdate=April 27, 2016}}</ref> The release made him what [[Interview (magazine)|Interview]] called an "underground hero in Atlanta."<ref name=":2" />
On July 2, 2015, 21 released a collaborative EP, ''Free Guwop'', with [[Sonny Digital]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.livemixtapes.com/mixtapes/35036/21-savage-free-guwop-ep.html|title=21 Savage - Free Guwop EP|work=LiveMixtapes|accessdate=27 April 2016}}</ref> It is a tribute EP to fellow rapper and influence [[Gucci Mane]]. On December 1, 2015, Abraham-Joseph released his second mixtape, ''[[Slaughter King]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hotnewhiphop.com/21-savage-slaughter-king-new-mixtape.116157.html|title=21 Savage - Slaughter King - Download & Listen [New Mixtape]|author=Rose Lilah|date=2 December 2015|work=HotNewHipHop|accessdate=27 April 2016}}</ref>
===2016–present: ''Savage Mode'', ''Issa Album'' and ''Without Warning''=== [[File:21 Savage 2018 2.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:21%20Savage%202018%202.jpg|left|thumb|21 Savage in June 2018]] In June 2016, Abraham-Joseph was named as one of the "Freshman Class" of 2016 by ''[[XXL (magazine)|XXL]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2016/06/xxl-freshman-class-cover-2016/|title=XXL Freshman Class Cover 2016|last=|first=|date=June 13, 2016|website=XXL Magazine|publisher=[[Townsquare Media]]|access-date=May 6, 2018}}</ref> On July 15, 2016, Abraham-Joseph released his joint [[Extended play|EP]] [[Savage Mode]] with Atlanta-based record producer [[Metro Boomin]]. The EP gained international success and peaked at number 23 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]], which became their highest charting EP to date.<ref name="BB2002">{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/artist/7447109/21-savage/chart|title=21 Savage – Chart History: Billboard 200|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|accessdate=July 29, 2016}}</ref> He was on the cover of [[Fader (magazine)|''Fader'']].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hotnewhiphop.com/21-savage-and-futures-x-is-now-platinum-news.25668.html|title=21 Savage on the cover of Fader|last=Lilah|first=Rose|access-date=23 November 2016}}</ref> His single "[[X (21 Savage and Metro Boomin song)|X]]" featuring [[Future (rapper)|Future]] on the EP was confirmed by Billboard as going platinum in the US, being 21's 1st platinum record.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2016/11/21-savage-first-platinum-record-x/|title=21 Savage Gets His First Platinum Record With "X"|last=Weinstein|first=Max|date=November 22, 2016|website=|publisher=|accessdate=December 3, 2016}}</ref> On January 18, 2017, Abraham-Joseph announced that he had signed to [[Epic Records]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hiphopdx.com/news/id.42064/title.21-savage-inks-record-deal-with-epic-records#|title=21 Savage Inks Record Deal With Epic Records|accessdate=January 18, 2017}}</ref>
In 2017, his debut studio album, ''[[Issa Album]]'', reached at number two on the US ''Billboard'' 200 chart.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/7866158/21-savage-haim-billboard-200-albums-chart-top-10|title=21 Savage & Haim Debut in Top 10 on Billboard 200 Albums Chart|last=Caulfield|first=Keith|date=July 16, 2017|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|accessdate=July 17, 2017}}</ref> Its lead single, "[[Bank Account (song)|Bank Account]]", charted in the top 20 on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://headlineplanet.com/home/2017/08/08/hot-100-niall-horans-slow-hands-enters-top-15-21-savages-bank-account-top-20/|title=Hot 100: Niall Horan’s "Slow Hands" Enters Top 15, 21 Savage’s "Bank Account" Top 20|date=August 7, 2017|work=Headline Planet|access-date=August 9, 2017}}</ref> Later that year, he was featured on [[Post Malone]]'s single "[[Rockstar (Post Malone song)|Rockstar]]", which peaked at number one on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100, and broke several records.<ref name="XXL Magazine2" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2018/01/post-malone-rockstar-breaks-spotify-global-record/|title=Post Malone Breaks Spotify Global Record With ''Rockstar'' - XXL|website=XXL Magazine|publisher=Townsquare Media|access-date=2018-02-16}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/hip-hop/8031270/post-malone-rockstar-platinum-21-savage|title=Post Malone & 21 Savage's 'Rockstar' Is Now Certified Platinum|work=Billboard|access-date=2018-02-16}}</ref>
In April 2018, Abraham-Joseph had a guest appearance on [[Young Thug]]'s extended play ''[[Hear No Evil (Young Thug EP)|Hear No Evil]]'' along with fellow rappers [[Nicki Minaj]] and [[Lil Uzi Vert]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefader.com/2018/04/13/young-thug-hear-no-evil-nicki-minaj-21-savage|title=Young Thug drops Hear No Evil EP|last=Maicki|first=Salvatore|date=April 13, 2018|website=The Fader|access-date=May 6, 2018}}</ref> Later that month he also appeared on the single "Outstanding" by [[SahBabii]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/rap-music/new-music/2018/04/sahbabii-21-savage-new-song-outstanding/|title=Listen to SahBabii and 21 Savage's New Song "Outstanding"|last=India|first=Lindsey|date=April 20, 2018|website=XXL Magazine|publisher=Townsquare Media|access-date=May 2, 2018}}</ref> In March 21 he was featured on the single "Rover 2.0", which is part of [[BlocBoy JB]]'s [[Simi (mixtape)|Simi]] mixtape.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.stereogum.com/1988300/blocboy-jb-rover-2-0-feat-21-savage/music/|title=BlocBoy JB – "Rover 2.0" (Feat. 21 Savage)|last=Breihan|first=Tom|date=March 23, 2018|website=[[Stereogum]]|publisher=[[Eldridge Industries]]|access-date=May 1, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/rap-music/new-music/2018/05/blocboy-jb-simi-mixtape/|title=BlocBoy JB Drops 'Simi' Mixtape Featuring Drake, Lil Pump and More|last=Coleman II|first=C. Vernon|date=May 4, 2018|website=XXL Magazine|publisher=Townsquare Media|access-date=May 9, 2018}}</ref> In the following month, he was featured on [[Ty Dolla Sign]]'s "Clout", which is part of the upcoming deluxe edition of last years's ''[[Beach House 3]]''.<ref>{{cite magazine|last=Darville|first=Jordan|date=May 9, 2018|title=Ty Dolla $ign recruits 21 Savage for "Clout"|url=http://www.thefader.com/2018/05/09/ty-dolla-sign-21-savage-clout|magazine=The Fader|location=New York City|access-date=May 11, 2018}}</ref>
On October 31, 2018, [[Halloween]], Abraham-Joseph posted on his Instagram a picture of a man in silhouette jumping in the air in the direction away from a large blaze. In the bottom right corner of the picture there is a "Parental Advisory" notice, as there oftentimes is on the cover of rap releases. Abraham-Joseph also tagged Metro Boomin in the post. For these reasons, some speculated it to be a sequel to 2017's ''Without Warning'' record. However, it turned out to be the cover for Metro’s debut solo album, ''[[Not All Heroes Wear Capes]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/p/BpnfcqeBtAT/?hl=en&taken-by=21savage|title=Saint Laurent Don on Instagram: "y’all know what season it is @metroboomin 4L"|website=Instagram|language=en|access-date=2018-11-01}}</ref>
== Musical style == Called "one of the last street niggas left making music" by frequent collaborator Metro Boomin,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thefader.com/2015/10/01/feature-21-savage|title=Meet 21 Savage, Atlanta’s Most Respected New Rapper|work=The FADER|access-date=2018-07-10|language=en}}</ref> Abraham-Joseph's music is heavily autobiographic with emphasis on violent and criminal aspects of his past including murder and drug dealing.<ref name=":12" />
==Controversies== In 2018, 21 Savage reportedly started a movement called "Guns Down, Paintballs Up" which was intended to reduce gun violence.<ref name="CBS2">{{cite web|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/paintball-wars-initially-intended-to-curb-gun-violence-linked-to-2-deaths/|title="Paintball wars," initially intended to curb gun violence, linked to 2 deaths|last=Diaz|first=Adriana|date=May 1, 2018|website=[[CBS News]]|access-date=May 2, 2018}}</ref> The head of the [[Detroit Police Department]], [[James Craig (police chief)|James Craig]], described the movement as "well-intentioned, however, misguided".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/paint-up-guns-down-detroit-paintball-arrests-2018-04-27/|title=Detroit police cracks down on citywide "paintball wars"|author=<!--Not stated-->|date=April 21, 2018|website=CBS News|access-date=May 2, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation-now/2018/04/27/detroit-police-crack-down-citywide-paintball-wars/560019002/|title=Detroit police to crack down on citywide 'paintball wars'|last1=Patterson|first1=Brandon|last2=Zaniewski|first2=Ann|date=April 27, 2018|website=[[USA Today]]|publisher=[[Gannett Company]]|access-date=May 2, 2018}}</ref> The movement has been linked to several cases of property crime and homicide.<ref name="CBS2" /><ref name="USA Today2">{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation-now/2018/05/01/paintball-wars-spate-shootings/569407002/|title=Paintball shootings splatter cities after rapper calls for swapping handguns for paintball weapons|last1=Mensch|first1=Jessica|last2=Luthern|first2=Ashley|date=May 1, 2018|website=USA Today|publisher=Gannett Company|access-date=May 2, 2018}}</ref> 21 Savage has not commented on the matter, although he paid for the funeral of a 3-year old who was killed in a related incident.<ref name="CBS2" /><ref name="USA Today2" />
Controversy arose after Abraham-Joseph pulled out a firearm during a pool party on June 11, 2018.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/hip-hop/8460380/21-savage-gun-atlanta-brawl|title=21 Savage Draws Gun During Atlanta Pool Party Brawl|work=Billboard|access-date=2018-07-10}}</ref> Abraham-Joseph was given the firearm by a friend after seeing an opposing crew member also pull out a pistol.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.vibe.com/2018/06/21-savage-pull-out-a-gun/|title=21 Savage Pulls Out A Gun During A Brawl: Watch|date=2018-06-10|work=Vibe|access-date=2018-07-10}}</ref>
==Personal life== Abraham-Joseph practices the African religion [[Ifá]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://noisey.vice.com/en_us/article/zn4pn3/21-savage-breakfast-club-interview-2016|title=No Joke, You Should Definitely Watch 21 Savage's Entire 'Breakfast Club' Interview|last=Witmer|first=Phil|date=August 4, 2016|website=[[Noisey]]|publisher=[[Vice Media]]|access-date=May 6, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefader.com/2016/11/21/21-savage-cover-story-interview|title=Savage World|last=Barshad|first=Amos|date=November 21, 2016|website=The Fader|access-date=May 6, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://pulse.ng/gist/21-savage-the-hottest-rapper-in-america-worships-ifa-id5816327.html|title=21 Savage, the hottest rapper in America worships Ifa|last=Tayo|first=Ayomide O.|access-date=May 6, 2018}}</ref> In summer 2017, Savage started dating model [[Amber Rose]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2018/02/amber-rose-sniffs-21-savages-underwear/|title=Amber Rose Sniffs 21 Savage's Underwear When She Misses Him|last=Coleman II|first=C. Vernon|date=February 10, 2018|work=XXL Magazine|accessdate=February 10, 2018|publisher=Townsquare Media}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bet.com/music/2018/02/14/21-savage-valentines-day-gift-amber-rose.html|title=21 Savage Got The Sexiest Gift From Amber Rose For Valentine's Day|date=February 14, 2018|work=[[BET]]|accessdate=March 16, 2018}}</ref> As of March 2018, the couple has separated.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://people.com/music/amber-rose-21-savage-split/|title=Amber Rose and 21 Savage Split After Nearly 2 Years of Dating|last1=Mizoguchi|first1=Karen|last2=Rubenstein|first2=Janine|date=March 14, 2018|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|accessdate=March 15, 2018}}</ref>
He also has three children.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.capitalxtra.com/features/facts/21-savage/does-have-kids/|title=Does 21 Savage have any kids?|author=<!--Not stated-->|website=[[Capital XTRA]]|access-date=May 6, 2018}}</ref>
== Filmography == 21 Savage is currently working on his first movie, "'''''Issa Movie'''''".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ballerstatus.com/2017/12/10/21-savage-delivers-trailer-issa-movie/|title=21 Savage Delivers Trailer for "ISSA" Movie|date=2017-12-10|work=BallerStatus.com|access-date=2018-11-04|language=en-US}}</ref>
21 Savage also worked on a [[YouTube]] [[miniseries]] named "'''''Year 2100'''''".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2017/06/21-savage-animated-web-series-the-year-2100/|title=21 Savage Gets Animated in New Web Series ‘The Year 2100’ - XXL|website=XXL Mag|language=en|access-date=2018-11-04}}</ref>
==Discography== {{Main|21 Savage discography}}
===Studio albums===
* ''[[Issa Album]]'' (2017) * ''[[Without Warning (21 Savage, Offset and Metro Boomin album)|Without Warning]]'' {{small|(with [[Offset (rapper)|Offset]] and [[Metro Boomin]])}} (2017)
===Extended plays===
* ''[[Free Guwop]]'' (2015) * ''[[Savage Mode]]'' {{small|(with Metro Boomin)}} (2016)
===Mixtapes===
* ''[[The Slaughter Tape]]'' (2015) * ''[[Slaughter King]]'' (2015)
==Awards and nominations== {| class="wikitable" |- !Year !Award !Category !Nominated Work !Result |- | rowspan="10"| 2018 | [[BET Awards 2017|BET Awards]] | [[BET Award for Best New Artist|Best New Artist]] | rowspan="2"|Himself | {{nom}} |- | rowspan="2"| [[2018 iHeartRadio Music Awards|iHeartRadio Music Awards]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/8240363/iheartradio-music-award-winners-2018-complete-list-winners-1089542|title=iHeartRadio Music Award Winners 2018: Complete List|last=Atkinson|first=Katie|date=March 11, 2018|work=Billboard|access-date=March 11, 2018}}</ref> | Best New Hip-Hop Artist | {{nom}} |- | Hip-Hop Song of the Year | "[[Rockstar (Post Malone song)|Rockstar]]" {{small|(with [[Post Malone]])}} | {{nom}} |- | rowspan="5" |[[2018 Billboard Music Awards|''Billboard'' Music Awards]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/bbma/8343598/billboard-music-awards-2018-nominations-list|title=Billboard Music Awards 2018 Nominations: See the Full List|date=April 17, 2018|work=Billboard|access-date=April 17, 2018}}</ref> |[[Billboard Music Award for Top New Artist|Top New Artist]] |Himself |{{nom}} |- |[[Billboard Music Award for Top Hot 100 Song|Top Hot 100 Song]] | rowspan="6" | "Rockstar" {{small|(with Post Malone)}} | {{nom}} |- |[[Billboard Music Award for Top Streaming Song (Audio)|Top Streaming Song (Audio)]] | {{nom}} |- |Top Collaboration | {{nom}} |- |[[Billboard Music Award for Top Rap Song|Top Rap Song]] | {{won}} |- | [[ASCAP Awards|ASCAP Pop Awards]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ascap.com/news-events/awards/2018/pop-awards|title=2018 Ascap Pop Awards|website=ASCAP|access-date=April 24, 2018}}</ref> | Winning Songs | {{nom}} |- | [[2018 MTV Video Music Awards|MTV Video Music Awards]] | Song of the Year | {{won}} |}

{{Infobox musical artist | name = 2562 | background = non_performing_personnel | birth_name = Dave Huismans | alias = A Made Up Sound
Dogdaze | birth_date =1979 | death_date = | origin = [[The Hague]], [[Netherlands]] | instrument = | genre = [[Future garage]], [[broken beat]], [[dubstep]], [[techno]], [[outsider house]] | occupation = [[Record producer]], [[Disc jockey|DJ]] | years_active = | label = [[Tectonic (record label)|Tectonic]] }} '''Dave Huismans''' (born 1979), better known by his [[stage name]] '''2562,''' is a musician from [[The Hague]], [[Netherlands]].{{cite web|url=http://www.residentadvisor.net/feature.aspx?926|title=2562: Dubstep in the area|date=21 July 2008|work=Resident Advisor|accessdate=17 April 2010}} Having previously released records of various musical styles under the monikers '''A Made Up Sound''' and '''Dogdaze''',{{cite web|author=zzzzamuel zzzztrang |url=http://www.drownedinsound.com/articles/3432763 |title=Reviews - Album - 2562 |publisher=Drowned in Sound |date=2008-06-10 |accessdate=2010-09-08}} Huismans created 2562, under which his output is generally described as [[dubstep]].{{cite web|url=http://www.boomkat.com/item.cfm?id=95455 |title=2562, Aerial |publisher=Boomkat |date= |accessdate=2010-09-08}}{{cite web|url=http://www.theskinny.co.uk/article/42836-2562-aerial |title=2562 - Aerial |publisher=The Skinny |date=2008-05-23 |accessdate=2010-09-08}}{{cite web|url=http://www.dustedmagazine.com/reviews/4332 |title=Dusted Reviews: 2562 - Aerial |publisher=Dustedmagazine.com |date=2008-06-02 |accessdate=2010-09-08}} He is known for producing dubstep that takes influence from techno as well.De opkomst van dubstep in de media ''[https://thesis.eur.nl/pub/10274/ Dr P.Berkers]'' The debut 2562 album, ''Aerial'' (Tectonic Records, 2008), was released to favourable reviews.{{cite web|url=http://www.soundsoftheuniverse.com/releases/?id=12324 |title=Sounds of the Universe — 2562 — Aerial |publisher=Soundsoftheuniverse.com |date= |accessdate=2010-09-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110524061734/http://www.soundsoftheuniverse.com/releases/?id=12324 |archivedate=2011-05-24 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.factmagazine.co.uk/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=517&Itemid=26 |title=2562's 'Aerial' view |publisher=FactMagazine |date=2010-08-31 |accessdate=2010-09-08}}The Next Dubstep''[https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2008/aug/25/sceneandheard The Guardian]'' ==Discography== ===Albums=== * ''In Dog We Trust'' (2006), Dogdaze Productions – as Dogdaze * ''Aerial'' (2008), Tectonic – as 2562 * ''Shortcuts'' (produced 2004, released 2008), - as Made Up Sound * ''Unbalance'' (2009), Tectonic – as 2562 * ''Fever'' (2011), When In Doubt – as 2562 * ''Air Jordan'' (2012), When In Doubt - as 2562 * ''The new today'' (2014), When In Doubt - as 2562 ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [https://myspace.com/2562dub 2562] on [[Myspace]] * {{Discogs artist | artist = 2562 | name = 2562 }} * [http://www.factmagazine.co.uk/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=581&Itemid=27 ''FactMagazine'' interview (05/2008)] * [http://www.beatportal.com/feed/item/2562-video-interview/ Beatportal interview (10/2008)] * [https://archive.is/20130205211702/http://www.vectormeldrew.com/2009/08/2562-unbalance-album-artwork/ 2562 Unbalance Artwork Designer (10/2008)] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:2562}} [[Category:1979 births]] [[Category:Dubstep musicians]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Musicians from The Hague]]

{{Infobox musical artist |image = |caption = |name = 2Play
(Wesley Johnson) |background = solo_singer |birth_name = Wesley Johnson |alias = 2Play, Wesley J, Special T |birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1977|7|22}} |death_date = |origin = London, England |genre = [[Dancehall]], [[reggae]], [[contemporary R&B|R&B]], [[hip hop music|hip hop]], [[UK garage]] |occupation = Musician, record producer, songwriter, rapper |years_active = 1997–present |associated_acts = [[Raghav]], Jucxi D, [[Maxi Priest]], [[Moni]], [[Naila Boss]], Thomas Jules |website = }} {{about|the British musician|the article about a multiplayer game of two players|Two-player game|the article about a multiplayer video game|Two-player video game}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2012}} {{Use British English|date=July 2012}} '''Wesley Johnson''' (born 1977), known by his stage name '''2Play''',Graham Betts Complete UK Hit Albums 1956-2005 2005 - Page 330 "Raghav Mathur (bom 1983) who was educated at ... He won the 2004 MOBO Award for Best Collaboration with 2Play and Jucxi for So Confused." is a British musician, record producer, and former [[mixed martial artist]]. ==Music career== 2Play is a [[Music of Black Origin Awards|MOBO]] Award–winning record producer and musician.{{cite web|url=http://acharts.us/performer/2play|title=2play - Music Charts|publisher=}} He is best known for songs with the Canadian-Indian singer [[Raghav]], as well as collaborations with a number of artists including Jucxi D, [[Naila Boss]], Thomas Jules and Moni. 2Play first entered the music scene in 1997 as a [[UK garage]] producer under the alias Special T.{{cite web|url=https://www.discogs.com/artist/291524-Special-T|title=Special T|publisher=}} He has had two UK [[Top 40|Top 10]] [[hit single]]s: "So Confused" (featuring Raghav and Jucxi) and "It Can't Be Right" (featuring Raghav and Naila Boss).{{cite book | first= David | last= Roberts | year= 2006 | title= British Hit Singles & Albums | edition= 19th | publisher= Guinness World Records Limited | location= London | isbn= 1-904994-10-5 | page= 571}} A [[cover version|cover]] of [[Kevin Lyttle]]'s "[[Turn Me On (Kevin Lyttle song)|Turn Me On]]" featuring Raghav and Jucxi appeared as a B-side to the single "So Confused". In 2005, "So Confused" also won "Best Single" at the [[UK Asian Music Awards]].{{cite web|url=http://www.wass-up.com/ukama2005.php |title=Artists unite to celebrate British Asian Music |accessdate=24 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110110150402/http://wass-up.com/ukama2005.php |archivedate=10 January 2011 }} He has produced cover versions of such songs as [[George Michael]]'s "[[Careless Whisper]]" (featuring Thomas Jules and Jucxi D) and [[Maxi Priest]]'s "[[Close to You (Maxi Priest song)|Close to You]]" (featuring Moni). ===Discography=== ====Singles==== {|class="wikitable" |- !rowspan="2"| Year !rowspan="2"| Single !| Chart positions !rowspan="2"| Album |- !width="30"|[[UK Singles Chart]] |- || 2003 |"So Confused" featuring [[Raghav]] and Jucxi | style="text-align:center;"| 6 |rowspan="2"| [[Storyteller (Raghav album)|Raghav album ''Storyteller'']] |- || 2004 |"It Can't Be Right" featuring [[Raghav]] and [[Naila Boss]] | style="text-align:center;"| 8 |- || 2005 |"[[Careless Whisper]]" featuring Thomas Jules and Jucxi D | style="text-align:center;"| 29 | |- || 2007 |"[[Close to You (Maxi Priest song)|Close to You]]" featuring Moni | style="text-align:center;"| – | |- || 2009 |"That's What the Girls Like" featuring [[Maxi Priest]], Moni and Jucxi D | style="text-align:center;"| – | |} ==Mixed martial arts== {{Infobox martial artist | name = Wesley Johnson | other_names = | image = | image_size = 200px | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1977|7|22|df=y}} | birth_place = London, England | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | residence = | nationality = English | height = | weight = | weight_class = [[Lightweight (MMA)|Lightweight]] | reach = | style = [[Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu]], [[Karate]] | stance = | fighting_out_of = London, England | team = | rank = ''[[Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu ranking system#Brown belt|brown belt]] in [[Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu]]''
''[[black belt (martial arts)|black belt]] in [[Karate]]'' | years_active = | mma_kowin = 1 | mma_subwin = 4 | mma_decwin = | mma_koloss = 1 | mma_subloss = | mma_decloss = | mma_draw = | mma_nc = 1 | sherdog = 34903 }} In addition to his music career, Johnson was also a [[mixed martial artist]]. He fought for [[Cage Rage]] and [[Ultimate Challenge MMA]].{{cite web|author=Sherdog.com |url=http://www.sherdog.com/fighter/Wesley-Johnson-34903 |title=Wesley Johnson MMA Stats, Pictures, News, Videos, Biography, and More |publisher=Sherdog.com |accessdate=22 March 2010}} ===Record=== {{MMArecordbox |draws=0 |ko-wins=1 |ko-losses=1 |sub-wins=4 |sub-losses=0 |dec-wins=0 |dec-losses=0 |nc=1 }}
