{{pp|small=yes}} {{Use mdy dates|date=April 2018}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = 2 Chainz | background = solo_singer <!-- includes rappers --> | image = 2 Chainz May 2014 2 (cropped).jpg | caption = 2 Chainz in May 2014 | birth_name = Tauheed Epps | alias = {{hlist|Tity Boi|Drenchgod}} | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|mf=yes|1977|09|12}} | birth_place = [[College Park, Georgia]], U.S. | genre = [[Hip hop music|Hip hop]] | occupation = {{flatlist| * Rapper * songwriter * television personality * activist * actor }} | years_active = 1997–present | label = {{flatlist| * [[Def Jam Recordings|Def Jam]] * [[#The Real University|T.R.U.]] }} | associated_acts = <!-- Exercise constraint and add only the NOTABLE acts associated with 2 Chainz; see [[Template:Infobox musical artist#Associated acts]] for criteria --> {{flatlist| * [[Playaz Circle]] * [[Gucci Mane]] * [[Jeezy]] * [[Lil Wayne]] * [[Ludacris]] * [[Migos]] }} | website = {{url|http://www.2chainz.com}} }} '''Tauheed Epps''' (born September 12, 1977),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rap-up.com/2012/09/13/video-2-chainz-gets-his-big-booty-birthday-wish/ |title=2 Chainz Gets His Big Booty Birthday Wish |website=Rap-Up.com|accessdate=June 15, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportsagents.net/index.php/content/content17/176-2-chainz |title=2 Chainz |website=Sportsagents.net |date= |accessdate=May 7, 2016}}</ref> known professionally as '''2 Chainz''' (formerly '''Tity Boi'''), is an American rapper, songwriter, television personality, activist, and actor. Born and raised in [[College Park, Georgia]], he initially gained recognition for being one-half of the [[Southern hip hop]] duo [[Playaz Circle]], alongside his longtime friend and fellow rapper Earl "Dolla Boy" Conyers. The duo was signed to fellow Georgia-based rapper [[Ludacris]]' [[Disturbing tha Peace]] label, and are best known for their debut single "[[Duffle Bag Boy]]".
In February 2012, Epps signed a solo [[record deal]] with [[Def Jam Recordings]], an imprint of [[Universal Music Group]]. The following August, he released his debut studio album ''[[Based on a T.R.U. Story]]'', to mixed reviews.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/music/based-on-a-tru-story/2-chainz/critic-reviews |title=Critic Reviews for Based on a T.R.U. Story |website=Metacritic |date= |accessdate=November 20, 2012}}</ref> The album spawned three successful singles: "[[No Lie (2 Chainz song)|No Lie]]," "[[Birthday Song]]," and "[[I'm Different (2 Chainz song)|I'm Different]]", all of which charted in the top 50 of the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] and were certified Gold or higher by the [[Recording Industry Association of America|RIAA]], along with the album being certified Gold. His second studio album ''[[B.O.A.T.S. II: Me Time]]'' was released on September 11, 2013. It was supported by the singles "[[Feds Watching]]" and "[[Used 2]]". Mr. Chainz began working with the TV Network [[Viceland]] on a show called [[Most Expensivest]], which debuted its first episode on November 15, 2017, and is currently in its second season.
==Early life and education== 2 Chainz was born '''Tauheed Epps''' in [[College Park, Georgia]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usmagazine.com/entertainment/news/2-chainz-might-run-for-mayor-of-college-park-georgia-2015281|title=2 Chainz Might Run for Mayor of College Park, Georgia: Rapper Gets Political|website=Us Weekly|first=Madeline|last=Boardman|date=January 28, 2015|accessdate=November 8, 2016}}</ref> He attended [[North Clayton High School]], where he played basketball and graduated second in his class.<ref name=beast>{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2016/03/27/2-chainz-is-no-donald-trump-fan.html|title=2 Chainz Is No Donald Trump Fan|website=The Daily Beast|first=Marlow|last=Stern|date=March 27, 2016|accessdate=November 8, 2016}}</ref> While in high school, he dealt [[marijuana]] and was arrested for felony [[cocaine]] possession when he was 15 years old.<ref name=beast/> He later attended [[Alabama State University]] on a scholarship, and played on its basketball team from 1995 to 1997.<ref name="sports-reference">{{cite web|url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cbb/players/tauheed-epps-1.html|title=Tauheed Epps|accessdate=July 4, 2017|work=S-R CBB}}</ref><ref name=espn>{{cite web |url=http://espn.go.com/blog/playbooksounds/post/_/id/3120/how-good-was-2-chainz-at-basketball |website=espn.go.com |publisher=ESPN |title=How good was 2 Chainz at basketball? |accessdate=December 10, 2012}}</ref>
When asked by ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' about longstanding rumors that he had graduated from Alabama State with a 4.0 GPA, which had been widely reported on many sources including [[Wikipedia]], 2 Chainz said: "Don't believe anything on Wack-ipedia. There's a lot of false stuff on there, to the point that every time I try to fix one thing, something else comes out."<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/q-a-suddenly-2-chainz-is-everywhere-20120813 | title=Five Reasons Why 2 Chainz Should Make A Presidential Bid | work=The Observer | date=September 25, 2012 | accessdate=January 10, 2016 | author=Vanessa Quilantan}}</ref> In fact, he transferred to [[Virginia State University]] due to circumstances he was reluctant to speak about.<ref name=beast/> "I got into some trouble, went somewhere else, and came back. But I graduated, and that’s that. That was then," he said.<ref name=beast/>
==Career==
===1997–2010: Playaz Circle and Disturbing tha Peace=== Epps formed the hip hop duo [[Playaz Circle]] (the word "Playaz" being a [[bacronym]] for "Preparing Legal Assets for Years from A to Z")<ref name=dubmagazine>{{cite web|title=Playaz Circle|url=http://dubmagazine.com/stars/musicians/410-playaz-circle|work=Dub Magazine|publisher=Dub Publishing |accessdate=May 20, 2012}}</ref> in [[College Park, Georgia]] in 1997, with his high school friend Earl Conyers (known as Dolla Boy), while Epps adopted "Tity Boi" as his [[moniker]].<ref name=allmusicbio>{{cite web |last=Cordor|first=Cyril|title=Playaz Circle – Biography|url=http://allmusic.com/artist/playaz-circle-p733429/biography|work=[[Allmusic]]|publisher=[[Rovi Corporation]]|accessdate=May 20, 2012}}</ref> Following the release of an [[Independent music|independent album]] titled ''United We Stand, United We Fall'' (2002),<ref name=dubmagazine/> the duo were introduced to fellow Atlanta rapper [[Ludacris]], when he moved into their College Park apartment complex, whilst he was acting as a [[disc jockey|DJ]].<ref name=allmusicbio/> After taking interest in Playaz Circle, Ludacris began to record several songs with the group, playing some of them on his [[radio station]].<ref name=dubmagazine/>
Ludacris soon became one of the highest-selling rappers in the [[Southern United States]].<ref name=allmusicbio/> After hearing of their situation, Ludacris requested of Epps that the duo join his newly formed record label [[Disturbing Tha Peace]], a subsidiary of [[Def Jam Recordings]]. Epps agreed to sign, although Conyers did not officially join the label until his mother regained her health, a year after the initial signing.<ref name=allmusicbio/>
Their debut album ''[[Supply & Demand (Playaz Circle album)|Supply & Demand]]'', was released on October 30, 2007. The [[lead single]] and their debut single, "[[Duffle Bag Boy]]", became an urban [[hit single]]. The song features [[Lil Wayne]], and was performed by the duo at the [[BET Hip Hop Awards]]. The duo released their second studio album ''[[Flight 360: The Takeoff]]'', on September 29, 2009. In January 2010, Playaz Circle filmed a music video for their single "Big Dawg" [[featuring]] Lil Wayne and [[Birdman (entertainer)|Birdman]] at Studio Space Atlanta. Shortly afterwards, Epps left Disturbing tha Peace, a move he claimed was taken in order to advance his career. Although Ludacris was initially reluctant to allow Epps to leave the label (as he felt Epps could still prove financially successful), he eventually accepted the decision.<ref name=albumtitle>{{cite web|last=Vasquez|first=Andres|title=2 Chainz Reveals Album Title, Speaks On Leaving Ludacris' Label|url=http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/news/id.19019/title.2-chainz-reveals-album-title-speaks-on-leaving-ludacris-label|work=HipHopDX|publisher=Cheri Media Group|accessdate=May 20, 2012|date=March 15, 2012}}</ref>
===2011–12: Name change and ''Based on a T.R.U. Story''=== Throughout Epps's career, critics and fans alike have speculated the [[pseudonym]] "Tity Boi" was meant to be derogatory towards women, although he repeatedly denied such accusations.<ref name=vibenamechange>{{cite web|title=2 Chainz Opens Up About Why He Was Named 'Tity Boi,' T.R.U. Realigion Mixtape, and his Use of Codeine Syrup. 2 Chainz also collaborated with 8 Rochester rapper "Dale Mahoney" on his mixtape "Jordans&Drugs" in 2012.|url=http://www.vibe.com/article/2-chainz-opens-about-why-he-was-named-tity-boi-tru-realigon-mixtape-and-his-use-codeine|work=[[Vibe (magazine)|Vibe]]|publisher=Vibe Media|accessdate=May 20, 2012|date=October 27, 2011}}</ref> In early 2011, Epps decided to change his stage name to '''2 Chainz,''' as he perceived it to be more "family friendly."<ref name=hiphopdxnamechange>{{cite web|last=Harling|first=Danielle|title=2 Chainz Explains His Decision To Drop Tity Boi As A Stage Name, Says 2 Chainz Is More "Family Friendly"|url=http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/news/id.18172/title.2-chainz-explains-his-decision-to-drop-tity-boi-as-a-stage-name-says-2-chainz-is-more-family-friendly|work=HipHopDX|publisher=Cheri Media Group|accessdate=May 20, 2012|date=January 3, 2012}}</ref> Following the name change, Epps released a [[mixtape]] entitled ''T.R.U. REALigion,'' which became his first mixtape to appear on the music charts, peaking at number 58 on the US ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Top R&B/Hip-Hop Albums]] chart.<ref>{{cite web|title=2 Chainz – Charts & Awards – ''Billboard'' Albums|url=http://allmusic.com/artist/2-chainz-p2450987/charts-awards|work=Allmusic|publisher=Rovi Corporation|accessdate=May 20, 2012}}</ref> Since the success of the mixtape, Epps has made numerous [[guest appearance]]s on tracks by prominent recording artists such as<ref name=vibenamechange/> Kanye West ("[[Mercy (GOOD Music song)|Mercy]]") and Nicki Minaj ("[[Beez in the Trap]]").
On March 24, 2012, Epps announced his debut [[studio album]], whose title he had changed to ''[[Based on a T.R.U. Story]]'' from its original title of ''T.R.U. to My REALigion,''<ref name=albumtitle/> was set for an August 14, 2012, release date.<ref name=boombox>{{cite web|last=Bark|first=Theo|title=2 Chainz, 'Based on a T.R.U. Story': Rapper Reveals Producers on LP, Speaks on Kanye West|url=http://www.theboombox.com/2012/04/03/2-chainz-kanye-west|work=The Boombox|publisher=[[AOL]]|accessdate=May 20, 2012|date=April 3, 2012}}</ref> The album's lead single, "[[No Lie (2 Chainz song)|No Lie]]," features Canadian rapper [[Drake (entertainer)|Drake]], and was released on May 8, 2012.<ref>{{cite web|title=No Lie (feat. Drake) – Single by 2 Chainz|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/no-lie-feat.-drake-single/id524552884|work=[[iTunes Store]]|publisher=[[Apple Inc.|Apple]]|accessdate=May 20, 2012}}</ref> On May 11, it was under speculation that Epps had signed to Kanye West's [[GOOD Music]] label, after West [[Twitter|tweeted]]: "2 Chainz is charging 100k for a verse now cause he's G.O.O.D!!!!!"<ref name=twitter>{{cite web |last=West |first=Kanye |title= 2 Chainz is charging 100k for a verse now cause he's G.O.O.D!!!!! |url=https://twitter.com/kanyewest/status/201078576676749312|work=Twitter |publisher=[[Twitter]] |accessdate=May 27, 2012 |date=May 11, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120710080218/http://twitter.com/kanyewest/status/201078576676749312|archivedate=July 10, 2012 }}</ref> However, Epps later denied those rumors, saying: "He just said I’m good, like I’m ill. But we was talking and I think I was jeopardizing my brand sometimes by doing the homeboy special. So I think he felt like we should just put that out there that we ain't doing no more of that."<ref>{{cite web|last=Horowitz |first=Steven J. |title=2 Chainz Responds To G.O.O.D. Music Signing Rumors |url=http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/news/id.19725/title.2-chainz-responds-to-good-music-signing-rumors |website=HipHop DX |date=May 12, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Cofr7i3d?url=http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/news/id.19725/title.2-chainz-responds-to-good-music-signing-rumors |archivedate=December 10, 2012 |deadurl=no |accessdate=December 10, 2012 |df= }}</ref> On May 30, 2012, [[Ciara]] revealed 2 Chainz was featured on "[[Sweat (Ciara song)|Sweat]]," the intended first single from her fifth studio album, ''[[Jackie (Ciara album)|One Woman Army]].''<ref>{{cite web|title=Ciara Announces New Album ''One Woman Army''|url=http://www.rap-up.com/2012/05/15/ciara-announces-new-album-one-woman-army-first-single-sweat/#more-125650|work=|website=[[Rap-Up]].com |accessdate=May 30, 2012}}</ref>
''Based on a T.R.U. Story'' debuted at number one on the US [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]], selling 147,000 copies in its first week.<ref name="Hip Hop Album Sales: The Week Ending 8/19/2012">{{cite web|last=Vazquez|first=Edwin|title=Hip Hop Album Sales: The Week Ending 8/19/2012|url=http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/news/id.20875/title.hip-hop-album-sales-the-week-ending-8-19-2012|publisher=Cheri Media Group|accessdate=August 22, 2012}}</ref> The album was met with mixed reviews, earning a score of 55 on [[metacritic]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/music/based-on-a-tru-story/2-chainz/critic-reviews |title=Critic Reviews for Based on a T.R.U. Story |website=Metacritic |date= |accessdate=October 26, 2013}}</ref> As of September 23, 2012, the album has sold 288,000 copies in the United States.<ref name="Hip Hop Album Sales: The Week Ending 9/23/2012">{{cite web|last=Paine|first=Jack|title=Hip Hop Album Sales: The Week Ending 9/23/2012 |website=HipHopDX |url=http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/news/id.21300/title.hip-hop-album-sales-the-week-ending-9-23-2012|publisher=Cheri Media Group|accessdate=September 26, 2012}}</ref> In September, Epps performed at the [[2012 MTV Video Music Awards]], alongside longtime friend [[Lil Wayne]]. After the release of his debut, ''Based on a T.R.U. Story,'' Epps made momentous strides. He facilitated his first solo worldwide tour, selling out most of its dates; he was nominated for over 13 [[BET Hip Hop Awards]],<ref>{{cite web|last=Murphy|first=Keith|title=Editor|url=http://v103.cbslocal.com/2012/10/10/kanye-west-2-chainz-kendrick-lamar-among-winners-at-bet-hip-hop-awards/|website=CBS Local}}</ref> bringing home 4 such trophies;<ref>{{cite web |last=Markman |first=Rob |url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1695223/kanye-west-2-chainz-bet-hip-hop-awards-winners-list.jhtml |website=mtv.com |publisher=MTV News |title=2012 BET Hip Hop Awards Belong To Kanye West, 2 Chainz |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CofUX5sW?url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1695223/kanye-west-2-chainz-bet-hip-hop-awards-winners-list.jhtml |archivedate=December 10, 2012 |accessdate=December 10, 2012 |df= }}</ref> he earned ''The Source'' Magazine’s "Man of the Year" award;<ref>{{cite web|last=Fitzgerald |first=Trent |url=http://popcrush.com/2-chainz-man-of-the-year-the-source-magazine/ |website=Popcrush |title=2 Chainz Crowned Man Of the Year by The Source Magazine |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Cog88Ltt?url=http://popcrush.com/2-chainz-man-of-the-year-the-source-magazine/ |archivedate=December 10, 2012 |accessdate=December 10, 2012 |df= }}</ref> he released a collaborative endeavor with ADIDAS,<ref>{{cite web|last=Crates |first=Jake |url=http://allhiphop.com/2012/11/21/2-chainz-featured-in-champs-sports-commericials-and-facebook-digital-game-for-adidas-originals/ |website=AllHipHop |title=2 Chainz Featured in Champs Sports Commercials and Facebook Digital Game for Adidas Originals |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CogIrmvk?url=http://allhiphop.com/2012/11/21/2-chainz-featured-in-champs-sports-commericials-and-facebook-digital-game-for-adidas-originals/ |archivedate=December 10, 2012 |accessdate=December 10, 2012 |df= }}</ref> and later Beats By Dre;<ref>{{cite web |last=Kathiya |first=Henna |url=http://rapfix.mtv.com/2012/11/21/2-chainz-azealia-banks-lil-wayne-and-more-star-in-beats-by-dre-ad/ |website=MTV RapFix |title=2 Chainz, Azealia Banks, Lil Wayne And More Star In Beats By Dre Ad |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CogSRorc?url=http://rapfix.mtv.com/2012/11/21/2-chainz-azealia-banks-lil-wayne-and-more-star-in-beats-by-dre-ad/ |archivedate=December 10, 2012 |accessdate=December 10, 2012 |df= }}</ref> and he was nominated for three [[Grammy Awards]], including Best Rap Album.<ref>{{cite web |last=Watson |first=Andrew |url=http://theversed.com/2012/12/10/2-chainz-discusses-grammy-nomination-for-rap-album-of-the-year-thanks-kanye-west-and-drake/ |website=The Versed |title=2 Chainz Discusses Grammy Nomination For Rap Album Of The Year, Thanks Kanye West And Drake |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CogaPVXo?url=http://theversed.com/2012/12/10/2-chainz-discusses-grammy-nomination-for-rap-album-of-the-year-thanks-kanye-west-and-drake/ |archivedate=December 10, 2012 |accessdate=December 10, 2012 |df= }}</ref>
===2012–15: ''B.O.A.T.S. II: Me Time'' and ''Collegrove''=== {{Main|B.O.A.T.S. II: Me Time|ColleGrove}} In late 2012, Epps stated once he completed the [[Based on a T.R.U. Story|B.O.A.T.S.]] concert tour, he would reenter the studio. In November 2012, he revealed he was three songs deep into his second studio album. The album's estimated release date was April 2013.<ref name="www.hiphopdx.com">{{cite web | last = | first = | title = 2 Chainz Has Three Songs Recorded For Sophomore LP | url = http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/news/id.21735/title.2-chainz-has-three-songs-recorded-for-sophomore-lp | website=HipHopDX | date = | accessdate = November 2, 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/features/2013/01/xxl-presents-the-35-most-anticipated-albums-of-2013-3/#18 |title=XXL Presents... The 35 Most Anticipated Albums of 2013 – XXL |work=Xxlmag.com |date=January 14, 2013 |accessdate=October 26, 2013}}</ref> The rapper made a guest appearance on [[NBC]]'s ''[[Law & Order: Special Victims Unit]]'' in an episode that aired May 8, 2013.<ref name="past">{{cite web|url=http://tvline.com/2013/04/09/law-and-order-svu-season-14-cast-kathryn-erbe/|title=''Law & Order: SVU'' Exclusive: Kathryn Erbe Returns for 'Big' Fin Episode|work=TVLine.com|accessdate=April 9, 2013}}</ref> He also appeared as himself in the second season (episode 16, titled "...And Just Plane Magic") of the [[CBS]] sitcom ''[[2 Broke Girls]],'' where he travels on the same private planes as the two main characters.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/news/id.22638/title.2-chainz-guest-stars-on-2-broke-girls- |title=2 Chainz Guest Stars On "2 Broke Girls" |accessdate=May 17, 2013 |website=www.hiphopdx.com}}</ref> On May 23, 2013, he announced that his second studio album ''[[B.O.A.T.S. II: Me Time]]'' will be released on September 10, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|last=Paine |first=Jake |url=http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/news/id.24073/title.2-chainz-announces-sophomore-solo-album-release-date/ |title=2 Chainz "B.O.A.T.S. II: Me Time" Release Date, Tracklist & Production Credits | Get The Latest Hip Hop News, Rap News & Hip Hop Album Sales |website=HipHop DX|date=August 22, 2013 |accessdate=October 26, 2013}}</ref> On June 2, 2013, Epps premiered the first single from the album, titled "Feds Watching," at the [[WQHT|Hot 97]]'s Summer Jam. The song featured [[Pharrell Williams]], and it was recorded on 2013 Grammy Awards night.<ref>{{cite web|last=Langhorne |first=Cyrus |url=http://www.sohh.com/2013/06/2_chainz_has_the_feds_watching_at_summer.html |title=2 Chainz Has The "Feds Watching" At Summer Jam [Video |website=Sohh.Com |date=June 3, 2013 |accessdate=October 26, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vibe.com/article/exclusive-pharrell-making-2-chainz-feds-watching-single |title=Exclusive: Pharrell On the Making Of 2 Chainz 'Feds Watching' Single |website=Vibe |date=June 5, 2013 |accessdate=October 26, 2013}}</ref> On June 15, Epps announced the title of his second album would be ''B.O.A.T.S. II: Me Time.''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.complex.com/music/2013/06/2-chainz-boats-ii-drake-hot-1079-atlanta-birthday-bash |title=2 Chainz B.O.A.T.S. II and Drake at Hot 107.9 Atlanta Birthday Bash |website=Complex |date= |accessdate=October 26, 2013}}</ref> The album was released, through Def Jam Recordings, on September 10, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2013/09/2-chainz-pissed-amount-albums-shipped/ |title=2 Chainz Is Pissed At The Amount Of Copies His Album Shipped – XXL |work=Xxlmag.com |date=September 10, 2013 |accessdate=October 26, 2013}}</ref>
''B.O.A.T.S. II: Me Time'' featured [[guest appearance]]s from [[Pharrell Williams]], [[Fergie (singer)|Fergie]], Drake, [[Lil Wayne]], [[Pusha T]], [[Mase]], [[Chrisette Michele]], [[Iamsu!]], [[T-Pain]], Dolla Boy, [[Rich Homie Quan]], and [[Lloyd (singer)|Lloyd]] among others. The album's [[Record production|production]] was handled by [[Diplo]], [[Mike WiLL Made It]], [[Drumma Boy]], [[J.U.S.T.I.C.E. League]], [[Mannie Fresh]], Wonder Arillo, Da Honorable C-Note and [[DJ Toomp]] among others.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rap-up.com/2013/08/22/tracklisting-2-chainz-boats-2-me-time/ |title=Tracklisting: 2 Chainz – ‘B.O.A.T.S. 2 #MEtime’ |website=Rap-Up.com |date=August 22, 2013 |accessdate=October 26, 2013}}</ref> It was also supported by the single "Used 2," along with the [[promotional single]]s "[[Where U Been? (song)|Where U Been?]]" and "Netflix." Upon the album's release, it was met with generally positive reviews from [[music critic]]s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/music/boats-ii-metime/2-chainz |title=B.O.A.T.S. II: #METIME Reviews |website=Metacritic |date= |accessdate=October 26, 2013}}</ref> It also faired decently commercially, debuting at number three on the US [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]], and number two on the [[Top R&B/Hip-Hop Albums]] chart selling 63,000 copies in its first week.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/5695587/keith-urban-edges-the-weeknd-for-no-1-debut-on-billboard-200 |title=Keith Urban Edges the Weeknd for No. 1 Debut on Billboard 200 |work=Billboard |date=December 1, 2012 |accessdate=October 26, 2013}}</ref>
On October 23, 2013, Epps revealed that he had begun working on his third studio album immediately following the release of ''B.O.A.T.S. II''. He also stated he had the first single from his third album ready for release and that he still wanted to get [[Jay-Z]] featured on the album.<ref>{{cite web|author=*Please enter your name. |url=http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2013/10/2-chainz-working-third-album/ |title=Xxlmag.com |work=Xxlmag.com |date=October 26, 2013 |accessdate=May 7, 2016}}</ref> In November 2015, 2 Chainz revealed that he was releasing a joint album with [[Lil Wayne]], titled ''[[ColleGrove]].''<ref>{{cite web|title = 2 Chainz Announces Next Solo Album & Joint Project With Lil Wayne|url = http://www.hotnewhiphop.com/2-chainz-announces-next-solo-album-and-joint-project-with-lil-wayne-news.18632.html?image=1&gallery=0|website = HotNewHipHop|access-date = February 22, 2016}}</ref> On May 5, 2014, Epps released a brand new EP titled ''FreeBase'' for free digital download. It includes 7 songs, and includes features from [[Lil Boosie]], [[A$AP Rocky]], [[Rick Ross]] and more. The EP has earned over 200,000 downloads.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.datpiff.com/2-Chainz-FreeBase-mixtape.608133.html |title=Datpiff.com |website=Datpiff.com |date= |accessdate=May 7, 2016}}</ref> In January 2014 Epps released a promotional single titled "I'm A Dog."
===2016–present: ''Pretty Girls Like Trap Music'' & Rap Or Go To The League=== {{Main|Pretty Girls Like Trap Music}} On January 27, 2016 Epps released an EP titled "Felt Like Cappin" the EP was released via online streaming sites and [[iTunes]], the EP is promoted by the single "Back On That Bullshit" featuring [[Lil Wayne]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://listen.tidal.com/album/56705198 |title=TIDAL |website=Listen.tidal.com |date= |accessdate=May 7, 2016}}</ref>
Epps began 2016 with the March release of a 12 record collaborative album with rapper [[Lil Wayne]] titled ''[[ColleGrove]]''. The album was supposed to be the debut LP between 2 Chainz and [[Lil Wayne]], however, Wayne’s ongoing lawsuit with [[Cash Money Records]] prevented Wayne from being a primary artist on the album. Epps appears as the primary artist on the album with eight tracks featuring [[Lil Wayne]]. The album features prominent producers such as: [[Honorable C.N.O.T.E.]], [[Mike Will Made It]], [[Zaytoven]], [[TM88]], [[Metro Boomin]], [[London on da Track]], and more. ''[[ColleGrove]]'' received decent reviews from critics and fans.
Epps continued his work in 2016 with the August 5, release of mixtape ''[[Daniel Son; Necklace Don]]'', currently a 9 track mixtape that Epps released independently. ''[[Daniel Son; Necklace Don]]'' originally featured [[Drake (musician)|Drake]] and [[YFN Lucci]] on it but Epps chose to move the song, "Big Amount ft. Drake" to 2017 studio album ''[[Pretty Girls Like Trap Music]]'' due to its mass appeal on the mixtape and star power performance. ''[[Daniel Son; Necklace Don]]'' received a 3 out of 5 stars review from [[XXL (magazine)|XXL Magazine]].
2016 was wrapped up by Epps third mixtape titled ''[[Hibachi for Lunch]]'', released October 28. The seven track mixtape originally featured [[Quavo]], [[Gucci Mane]], [[Ty Dolla Sign]], and [[Future (rapper)|Future]] however, the song, "Good Drank ft. [[Quavo]] and [[Gucci Mane]]" was moved to ''[[Pretty Girls Like Trap Music]]''. Notable production was done by: [[Mike Will Made It]], K Swisha, Buddah Bless.
In 2017 Epps released his fourth studio album titled ''[[Pretty Girls Like Trap Music]]'' on June 16 by [[Def Jam Recordings]]. The album features [[Travis Scott]], [[Nicki Minaj]], [[Swae Lee]], [[Migos]], [[Jhené Aiko|Jhene Aiko]], [[Pharrell Williams]], and more. Album production was done by [[Mike Will Made It]], Buddah Bless, [[Mike Dean (record producer)|Mike Dean]], [[Murda Beatz]], and more. The album was supported by three official [[Single (music)|singles]]: "[[Good Drank]]", "[[It's a Vibe]]" and "4 AM". The album was also supported by a nationwide concert tour, as well as several [[Pop-up retail|pop-up shops]] in the US.<sup>[[Pretty Girls Like Trap Music#cite note-1|[1]]] [[Pretty Girls Like Trap Music#cite note-2|[2]]]</sup> 2 Chainz alluded to the album showing "growth and maturation." He stated the content would maintain its edginess while also elevating [[Trap music (hip hop)|trap music]] to a point where everyone can appreciate it. ''Pretty Girls Like Trap Music'' received widespread critical acclaim, with most critics citing the album as his best album yet.
On November 15, 2017, the first episode of [[Most Expensivest]] aired on the TV network [[Viceland]]. The show focuses on 2 Chainz visiting different locations offering the "most expensivest" goods and services. Each show covers a particular theme, with shows ranging from personal health to extravagant indulgences. The show offers a unique insight into products and services that have been created with the explicit intent on being exclusive and expensive. 2 Chainz offers a unique, and often humorous insight into the products, especially the ones he personally finds to be either amazing or ridiculous. The show has been renewed for a 20-episode third season set to air in early 2019.<ref>https://premieredate.news/tv-series/4568-most-expensivest.html</ref>
[[The Play Don't Care Who Makes It|''The Play Don’t Care Who Makes'']] It is the fourth EP released by Epps on February 8, 2018, by [[Def Jam Recordings]]. The EP consists of four songs one of which features appearances from [[YG (rapper)|YG]] and [[Offset (rapper)|Offset]] on the song "PROUD". Production was done by Minus, June James, Nonstop, Streetrunner, and more.
On February 19, 2018 Epps announced his new album Rap Or Go To The League which is set to be released in 2018.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/hip-hop/8208245/2-chainz-announces-new-album-rap-or-go-to-the-league|title=2 Chainz Announces New Album 'Rap or Go to the League'|work=Billboard|access-date=2018-07-06}}</ref>
==Personal life==
===Family=== Epps has two daughters, Heaven and Harmony.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.papermag.com/2015/05/2_chainz_legalization_voting_rights_fatherhood.php |title=2 Chainz Talks Legalization, Voting Rights & Fatherhood |website=Papermag |date=May 4, 2015 |accessdate=July 24, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://hiphopdx.com/news/id.25929/title.2-chainz-reveals-whether-he-lets-his-children-listen-to-his-music |title=2 Chainz Reveals Whether He Lets His Children Listen To His Music |website=HipHop DX |date=October 22, 2013 |accessdate=July 24, 2015}}</ref> On October 14, 2015, 2 Chainz welcomed his third child, a baby boy named Halo.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ballerstatus.com/2015/10/15/2-chainz-welcomes-third-child-a-baby-boy/ |title=2 Chainz Welcomes Third Child: A Baby Boy |website=BallerStatus.com |date=October 15, 2015}}</ref> On August 18, 2018, Epps married his longtime girlfriend and mother of his three children: Kesha Ward.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Pasquini |first1=Maria |title=2 Chainz Marries Longtime Love Kesha Ward in Miami Ceremony (with the Wests in Attendance!) |url=https://people.com/music/2-chainz-marries-kesha-ward/ |website=People |accessdate=28 August 2018 |date=August 18, 2018}}</ref>
===Legal issues=== At the age of 15, Epps was convicted of [[felony]] [[cocaine]] possession.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.complex.com/music/2013/07/2-chainz-breakfast-club-interview |title=2 Chainz Breakfast Club Interview |website=Complex |date=July 25, 2013 |accessdate=October 26, 2013}}</ref> On February 14, 2013, Epps was arrested in [[Maryland]] en route to a concert at [[University of Maryland Eastern Shore|UMES]] for [[Cannabis (drug)|marijuana]] possession. Epps was then cited and released.<ref>{{cite news|title=2 Chainz Arrested in Maryland on Marijuana Charge|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/2-chainz-arrested-in-maryland-on-marijuana-charge-20130215|newspaper=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=February 15, 2013<!-- 1:35 PM-->}}</ref>
On June 11, 2013, Epps was arrested while on board a departing flight at [[LAX]] airport for possession of a controlled substance after TSA agents found that his checked bag contained [[marijuana]] and [[promethazine]]. He was booked and charged with [[felony]] narcotics possession. Later that day he posted $10,000 bond and was released. He was due back in court on June 21, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2013/06/2-chainz-arrested-in-lax-for-possession-of-marijuana-and-promethazine/ |title=2 Chainz Arrested In LAX For Possession Of Marijuana And Promethazine – XXL |work=Xxlmag.com |date=June 11, 2013 |accessdate=October 26, 2013}}</ref> Two days previous, he was reportedly robbed at gunpoint outside a [[medical marijuana]] dispensary in [[San Francisco]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Rapper 2 Chainz robbed outside S.F. marijuana dispensary|url=http://blog.sfgate.com/crime/2013/06/10/rapper-2-chainz-robbed-outside-s-f-marijuana-dispensary/|agency=Associated Press|website=SFGate.com|accessdate=June 27, 2013|date=June 10, 2013}}</ref>
Just before midnight on August 21, 2013, Epps' tour bus was pulled over in [[Oklahoma City|Oklahoma City, Oklahoma]], because the passenger side taillights were out. The arresting officer reported that he smelled marijuana and saw smoke through the open door of the bus after he had stopped and pulled over the bus. The driver of the bus shut the door and told officers he was not authorized to allow them on the bus. The officer said the [[marijuana]] smell gave him probable cause to search, but the driver refused to open the door. After many attempts to enter, the bus was towed with the men still aboard to the police training center in Oklahoma City. Officers obtained a search warrant and the 10 men, including Epps, got off the bus. Police discovered two semi-automatic pistols and a 12-gauge pump shotgun, along with some prescription painkillers and marijuana residue, on the tour bus according to papers filed [[Oklahoma County, Oklahoma|Oklahoma County]] district Court.<ref>{{cite web|author=MICHAEL MCNUTT mmcnutt@opubco.com • |url=http://newsok.com/oklahoma-city-police-found-weapons-painkillers-on-rappers-tour-bus-court-papers-show/article/3878935 |title=Oklahoma City police found weapons, painkillers on rapper's tour bus, court papers show |website=News OK |date=September 3, 2013 |accessdate=October 26, 2013}}</ref>
==Business ventures==
In October 2016, he opened a line of hoodies called CEO Millionaires or Create Every Opportunity Millionaires.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hotnewhiphop.com/2-chainz-releases-new-line-of-ceo-millionaires-hoodies-news.24735.html? |title=2 Chainz releases line of hoodies |last=Goddard |first=Kevin |date=October 14, 2016 |website=[[Hotnewhiphop]] |access-date=October 14, 2016}}</ref> He also has his own line of sweaters called "Dabbing Sweaters."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hotnewhiphop.com/2-chainz-reveals-new-line-of-dabbing-santa-sweaters-news.25560.html? |title=2 Chainz releases line of sweaters called "Dabbin Sweaters"|last=Goddard |first=Kevin |date=November 19, 2016 |website=[[Hotnewhiphop]] |access-date=November 19, 2016}}</ref>
==Discography== {{Main|2 Chainz discography}} {{See also|Playaz Circle discography}} * ''[[Based on a T.R.U. Story]]'' (2012) * ''[[B.O.A.T.S. II: Me Time]]'' (2013) * ''[[ColleGrove]]'' (2016) * ''[[Pretty Girls Like Trap Music]]'' (2017) * ''Rap or Go to the League'' (2018)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.complex.com/music/2018/02/2-chainz-announces-next-album-rap-or-go-to-the-league|title=2 Chainz Announces His Next Album 'Rap or Go to the League'|work=[[Complex (magazine)|Complex]]|last=Elder|first=Sajae|date=February 17, 2018|accessdate=February 18, 2018}}</ref>
==The Real University== {{Infobox record label | name = The Real University | image = | image_size = | Also Known As = T.R.U., The Real U | founded = 2015 | founder = 2 Chainz (CEO) | status = Active | distributor = | country = United States | location = Atlanta, Georgia | url = }}
On January 6, 2015, 2 Chainz announced that he was starting his own independent record label "The Real University" (also known as "T.R.U."; or "The Real U").<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thesource.com/2015/01/06/2-chainz-announces-the-real-university-label-with-mix-tape-tru-jack-city/ |title=2 Chainz Announces The Real University Label With Mix-tape "Tru Jack City" |website=The Source |date= |accessdate=May 7, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=*Please enter your name. |url=http://www.xxlmag.com/rap-music/new-music/2015/01/2-chainz-featuring-cap-1-young-dolph-trap-house-stalkin/ |title=2 Chainz Featuring Cap 1 And Young Dolph "Trap House Stalkin" – XXL |work=Xxlmag.com |date=January 6, 2015 |accessdate=May 7, 2016}}</ref> The announcement also revealed that frequent collaborators Cap.1 & Skooly were signed. Additionally, they signed former [[Young Money]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.youngmoneyhq.com/artists/short-dawg/ |title=Short Dawg | Young Money Artist |website=Youngmoneyhq.com |date= |accessdate=May 7, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=<!-- author name --> Amir Diamond <!-- post timestamp --> |url=http://theboxhouston.com/9521719/find-out-why-short-dawg-aka-freh-is-no-longer-with-young-money/ |title=Find Out Why Short Dawg aka Fre$h Is No Longer With Young Money!! | 97.9 The Box |website=Theboxhouston.com |date= |accessdate=May 7, 2016}}</ref> artist Short Dawg, who is now known as Fresh. Along with the announcement of the label's founding, they also revealed they'd be releasing their debut mixtape ''TRU Jack City'' on January 27, 2015.
===Artists=== * 2 Chainz * Cap.1 * Skooly * Fresh (formerly known as Short Dawg) * C White
===Discography=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! scope="col" rowspan="1" style="width:10em;" | Artist ! scope="col" rowspan="1" style="width:10em;" | Title ! scope="col" rowspan="1" style="width:19em;" | Album details |- ! scope="row" | Cap.1 ! scope="row" | ''Bird Bath EP'' | * Released: January 13, 2015<ref>{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/bird-bath-ep/id956557565 |title=Bird Bath EP by Cap1 on iTunes |website=Itunes.apple.com |date=January 13, 2015 |accessdate=May 7, 2016}}</ref> * Label: The Real University * Format: Digital Download |}
==Awards and nominations==
===BET Awards=== {{awards table}} |- | style="text-align:center;" rowspan="8"| [[BET Awards 2013|2013]] | 2 Chainz | Best Male Hip-Hop Artist | {{nom}} |- | rowspan="2"|"[[Mercy (GOOD Music song)|Mercy]]" <small>(with [[Kanye West]], [[Big Sean]] and [[Pusha T]])</small> | Video of the Year | {{nom}} |- | rowspan="2"|Best Collaboration | {{nom}} |- | rowspan="2"|"[[No Lie (2 Chainz song)|No Lie]]" <small>(with [[Drake (musician)|Drake]])</small> | {{nom}} |- | rowspan="2"|Video of the Year | {{nom}} |- | rowspan="3"|"[[Fuckin' Problems]]" <small>(with [[ASAP Rocky|A$AP Rocky]], Drake and [[Kendrick Lamar]])</small> | {{nom}} |- | Best Collaboration | {{won}} |- | Coca-Cola Viewer's Choice | {{nom}} |- | style="text-align:center;" | [[BET Awards 2016|2016]] | rowspan="2"|2 Chainz & Lil Wayne | rowspan="2"|[[BET Award for Best Group|Best Duo/Group]] | {{nom}} |- | style="text-align:center;" rowspan="2"| [[BET Awards 2017|2017]] | {{nom}} |- | "[[No Problem (Chance the Rapper song)|No Problem]]" <small>(with [[Chance the Rapper]] and [[Lil Wayne]])</small> | [[BET Award for Best Collaboration|Best Collaboration]] | {{won}} |- {{end}}
===BET Hip Hop Awards=== {{awards table}} |- |rowspan="10"|2012<ref name="bet 2012">{{cite web |url=http://www.bet.com/shows/hip-hop-awards/2012/nominees.html |title= 2012 Hip Hop Awards Winners & Nominees|author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= April 25, 2012|website= bet.com |publisher= [[BET]] |access-date= June 9, 2016 }}</ref> |rowspan="4"|"Mercy" <small>(with [[Kanye West]], [[Big Sean]] and [[Pusha T]])</small> |Reese’s Perfect Combo Award (Best Collabo, Duo or Group) |{{won}} |- |Sweet 16: Best Featured Verse |{{won}} |- |Best Club Banger |{{nom}} |- |rowspan="2"|Best Hip Hop Video |{{nom}} |- |rowspan="2"|"No Lie" <small>(featuring [[Drake (rapper)|Drake]])</small> |{{nom}} |- |People's Champ Award |{{won}} |- |rowspan="7"|Himself |Rookie of the Year |{{won}} |- |Made You Look Award |{{nom}} |- |Hustler of the Year |{{nom}} |- |rowspan="2"|MVP of the Year |{{nom}} |- |rowspan="7"|[[2013 Bet Hip Hop Awards|2013]]<ref name="bet 2013">{{cite web |url=http://www.bet.com/shows/hip-hop-awards/2013/nominees.html |title= 2013 Hip Hop Awards Winners & Nominees|author=BET Staff |date= April 23, 2016|website= bet.com|access-date= April 30, 2017 }}</ref> |{{nom}} |- |Best Live Performer |{{nom}} |- |Made You Look Award |{{nom}} |- |rowspan="4"|"[[Fuckin' Problems]]"<br /><small>(with [[ASAP Rocky|A$AP Rocky]], Drake and [[Kendrick Lamar]])</small> |Best Hip Hop Video |{{nom}} |- |Reese’s Perfect Combo Award (Best Collabo, Duo or Group) |{{won}} |- |Best Club Banger |{{nom}} |- |People's Champ Award |{{nom}} |- |rowspan="2"|[[2016 BET Hip Hop Awards|2016]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bet.com/shows/hip-hop-awards/2016/photos/show/and-the-nominees-are.html#!HHA-PageProperties-1x1-HipHopVideo|title=And the Nominees Are|author=|date=|website=bet.com|accessdate=March 14, 2018}}</ref> |"[[Watch Out (2 Chainz song)|Watch Out]]" |Best Hip Hop Video |{{nom}} |- |"[[No Problem (Chance the Rapper song)|No Problem]]" |Sweet 16: Best Featured Verse |{{nom}} |- |}

Story]]'' | [[Best Rap Album]] | {{Nominated}} |- | rowspan="2"| "[[Mercy (GOOD Music song)|Mercy]]" <small>(with [[Kanye West]], [[Big Sean]] and [[Pusha T]])</small> | [[Best Rap Performance]] | {{Nominated}} |- | rowspan="3"| [[Best Rap Song]] | {{Nominated}} |- | style="text-align:center;"| [[56th Annual Grammy Awards|2014]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Grammys 2014: Winners list|url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/01/26/showbiz/grammys-winners-list/|work=CNN|accessdate=May 1, 2017|date=January 27, 2014}}</ref> | "[[Fuckin' Problems]]" <small>(with [[ASAP Rocky]], [[Drake (musician)|Drake]] and [[Kendrick Lamar]])</small> | {{nom}} |- | style="text-align:center;" rowspan="2"| [[59th Annual Grammy Awards|2017]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Grammy Awards 2017: The Full List Of Winners|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/02/12/514877528/grammy-awards-2017-the-full-list-of-winners|website=npr.org|accessdate=May 1, 2017|date=February 12, 2017}}</ref> | rowspan="2"| "[[No Problem (Chance the Rapper song)|No Problem]]" <small>(with [[Chance the Rapper]] and [[Lil Wayne]])</small> | {{nom}} |- | Best Rap Performance | {{won}} |- {{end}}

{{autobiography|date=September 2012}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = 3D Na'Tee | image = | image_size = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Samantha Davon James | alias = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1986|12|18}} | birth_place = [[New Orleans]], [[Louisiana]] | origin = [[New Orleans]], [[Louisiana]] | death_date = | death_place = | genre = [[Hip hop music|Hip hop]] | occupation = [[Rapping|Rapper]] | instrument = | years_active = 1994–present | label = Already Legendary, BMB | associated_acts = | website = {{URL|www.3DNATEE.com}} }}
'''Samantha Davon James''' (born December 18, 1986), better known by her stage name '''3D Na'Tee''', is an American [[rapper]], songwriter, and video director. She was born in [[New Orleans, Louisiana]] and grew up in the [[3rd Ward of New Orleans|3rd Ward]]. 3D Na'Tee has been featured on several national media outlets such as [[MTV]],<ref>{{cite web|title=MTV: SuckaFree Freestyle: 3D Na'Tee|url=http://www.mtv.com/videos/misc/651008/sucker-freestyle-3dnatee.jhtml|accessdate=May 8, 2011}}</ref> [[The Source (magazine)|The Source Magazine]],<ref name="thesource">{{cite web|title=THE SOURCE MAGAZINE: Top Up & Coming Female Rapper Releases Her Latest Project|url=http://www.thesource.com/articles/235038/}}</ref> [[XXL (magazine)|XXL Magazine]],<ref>{{cite web|title=XXL: Surviving The Times: Erick Sermon Talks About New Mixtape, Digital Label & Reviving Skills|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/features/2012/05/surviving-the-times-erick-sermon-talks-about-new-mixtape-digital-label-reviving-skills/}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=SHAHEEM REID: 5 STAR REVIEW FROM XXL'S EDITOR-AT-LARGE SHAHEEM REID & @TEAMSHAHEEM|url=http://3dnatee.com/main/?p=1340}}</ref> The Fader Magazine,<ref>{{cite web|title=THE FADER MAGAZINE: Features 3D Na'Tee - Lil Kim|url=http://www.thefader.com/index.php?s=na%27tee&submit.x=0&submit.y=0&submit=Go}}</ref> RapRadar<ref>{{cite web|title=RAPRADAR: RapRadar Search Features|url=http://rapradar.com/?s=3D+na%27tee&x=0&y=0}}</ref> and RapRehab.<ref>{{cite web|title=RAPREHAB: RapRehab's Featured Artist|url=http://raprehab.com/2012/08/3d-natee-new-orleans/}}</ref> She has also received attention from Louisiana newspapers and music magazines.<ref>{{cite web|title=THE SMOKING SECTION: 3D Na'Tee is Back and we have been invited to her Coronation|url=http://smokingsection.uproxx.com/TSS/2012/07/3d-natee-the-coronation-mixtape}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=NOLA.COM: 4X Nola HipHop Award Winner 3D Na'Tee Raises The Bar Again By Being The First Native HipHop Artist With A Mobile App|url=http://www.nola.com/music/index.ssf/2011/09/industry_influence_celebrates.html}}</ref>
==Early life== In her middle school years, 3D Na'Tee honed her skills by what is called in New Orleans, ribbin' (rib - ing). Most people know this as "Playing the Dozens". Someone would start a beat by beating on a lunch room table or a garbage can, and off she went, lyrically attacking someone who was bold enough to test her skill. The rhymes were mostly about what they were wearing, how lame they were, or silly they looked.
In 1999, she began recording with local label called '''Clientell Records'''. Over the next five years, she would record multiple mixtapes under the "Snypa Squad" and feature on other projects Clientell Records came out with. However, in 2006, a year after [[Hurricane Katrina]], Clientell Records dismantled and 3D Na'Tee, who had previously established herself as a battler rapper amongst the local rap scene in New Orleans, released her first mix tape project '''"3's Company Vol.1: The Rapper, The Hustler, the Diva"''' followed by '''Volume 2''' in 2007. After the release of her second project, she appeared on '''The Kush 2''' DVD which was produced by [[YMCMB]] president [[Mack Maine]]. The DVD featured other Cash Money/Young Money artist like [[Lil Wayne]], [[Nicki Minaj]], and [[Birdman (entertainer)|Birdman]] as well as [[Curren$y]] of [[Warner Bros. Records]]
==Career== After the local success of her first two releases and her critically acclaimed appearance on '''The Kush 2''', she released her third mix tape '''Heavy Is the head That Wears The Crown''' followed by a music video for a song she titled, '''Guess Who's Coming 2 Dinner'''. That video piqued the interest of [[G-Unit Records]] affiliate and [[Shade 45]] [[Sirius Satellite Radio|Sirius XM]] radio host Nelson Gomez who invited her to [[New York City|New York]] for an interview on his XM show as well as on rapper [[50 Cent|50 Cents']] wildly popular ThisIs50.com website. Soon after, the talk of her third release also got her featured in HipHop Weekly Magazine by [[Benzino]], former co-owner of [[The Source Magazine]].<ref>{{cite web|title=3DNATEE.COM: BIO|url=http://3dnatee.com/main/?page_id=28}}</ref>
Because of video releases like Guess Who's Coming 2 Dinner which spoofed many mainstream hip hop artists, 3D Na'Tee's music has been described as controversial and sometimes offensive.<ref>{{cite web|title=WOMEN OF HIPHOP: 3D Na'Tee Explains How HipHop Saved Her Life, Talks Female Rap, and More|url=http://thewomenofhiphop.com/2012/08/04/wohh-exclusive-3d-natee-explains-how-hip-hop-saved-her-lifetalks-female-rap-more/}}</ref> That song also shared the title of her for mix tape released in 2010.
'''Guess Who's Coming 2 Dinner''' (The Mixtape) lead to 3D Na'Tee being nominated for a total of 5 Nola HipHop Awards by her in her home town at the NOLA Hiphop Awards.<ref>{{cite web|title=OFFBEAT MAGAZINE: Nola HipHop Awards Nominees Finalized|url=http://www.offbeat.com/2010/10/14/nola-underground-hip-hop-award-nominees-finalized/}}</ref> She won three awards (the most awards won by a single artist) for '''Lyricist of the Year''', '''Mixtape of the Year''', and '''Female Artist of the Year'''.<ref>{{cite web|title=ASHLEE NICOLE SPILLS: Winners of the 2010 HipHop Awards Announced|url=http://www.ashleenicolespills.com/2010/10/20/winners-of-the-2010-nola-underground-hip-hop-awards/}}</ref> The mixtape included collaborations from [[Curren$y]] (courtesy of Warner Bros. Records), '''Ebony Eyez''',<ref>{{cite web|title=STL TODAY: Ebony Eyez Returns With A Story 2 Tell|url=http://www.stltoday.com/entertainment/music/ebony-eyez-returns-with-a-story-to-tell/article_6a65d3ae-d2bb-11e1-985c-0019bb30f31a.html}}</ref> and '''Babs Bunny''' (formally of [[Sean Combs|Sean "Diddy" Combs]]) founded group, [[Da Band]].<ref>{{cite web|title=SYFFAL: Forming Da Band|url=http://www.syffal.com/making-the-band}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=ALL MUSIC.COM: Da Band's Discography|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/da-band-mn0000764981}}</ref>
In early 2011 3D Na'Tee was featured on [[MTV|MTV's]] SuckerFree Freestyle<ref>{{cite web|title=MTV: SUCKERFREE FREESTYLE: 3DNATEE|url=http://www.mtv.com/videos/misc/651008/sucker-freestyle-3dnatee.jhtml}}</ref> hosted by [[DJ Envy]]. 3D Na'Tee and Syleena collaborated on a song called '''Go Head'''.<ref>{{cite web|title=RHAPSODY: Syleena Johnson|url=http://www.rhapsody.com/artist/syleena-johnson/album/chapter-v-underrated/track/go-head-feat-natee}}</ref>
July 27, 2011 3D Na'Tee released a video for '''Switch'''<ref>{{cite web|title=WORLDSTARHIPHOP: 3D Na'Tee's Switch|url=http://hp-www.worldstarhiphop.com/videos/video800.php?v=wshhd71614snrClf6d9H&set_size=1}}</ref> which she shot and edited herself. The song included several previously released instrumental versions of songs produced by super producer [[Timbaland]]. This video gained her a nomination for '''Director of the Year''' and an award for '''Video of the Year'''. Because of the momentum the Switch video gained the day of its release, Timbaland viewed it online and in less than 24 hours, flew 3D Na'Tee to [[The Hit Factory|Miami's Hit Factory Studio]] to work with her on her next project, The Coronation.<ref>{{cite web|title=THE FADER MAGAZINE: 3D Na'Tee - Lil Kim|url=http://www.thefader.com/2012/07/30/video-natee-lil-kim/#comments}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=ONWAX MAGAZINE: Rapper 3D Na'Tee shoots 'Wild' video in New Orleans, produced by Lex Luger|url=http://onwaxmagazine.com/owm/index.php/rapper-3d-natee-shoots-wild-video-in-new-orleans-produced-by-lex-luger/}}</ref> After several months spent traveling with Timbaland and other artist signed to his label, a contract was presented to 3D Na'Tee to sign to Timbaland's production company [[Mosley Music Group|Mosely Music Group]] and to be managed by members of Timbaland's management team. 3D Na'Tee and Timbaland later announced via [[Twitter]] that she was no longer a part of Timbaland's company because she decided not to sign the contract presented. In a later interview, 3D Na'Tee explained that there was no ill feelings towards Timbaland and cited her reasons for not signing were strictly because of contractual clauses that could not be agreed upon.<ref>{{cite web|title=DJSMALLZ.COM: INTERVIEW: SOUTHERN SMOKE TV! 3D NA'TEE (@3DNATEE) SPEAKS ON TURNING DOWN RECORD DEAL WITH TIMBALAND|url=http://www.djsmallz.com/blog/2012/5/18/interview-southern-smoke-tv-3d-natee-3dnatee-speaks-on-turni.html}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=WOMEN OF HIPHOP: [WOHH EXCLUSIVE]!|url=http://thewomenofhiphop.com/2012/08/04/wohh-exclusive-3d-natee-explains-how-hip-hop-saved-her-lifetalks-female-rap-more/}}</ref>
Exactly two years after 3D Na'Tee's last mix tape release, she released her highly anticipated street album ''The Coronation'' which featured artists like [[Keri Hilson]], Young Fletcher, and Lyrica Anderson. The Coronation also featured production from Mizay Entertainment's [[Lex Luger (producer)|Lex Luger]], [[Maybach Music Group|Maybach Music Group's]] Yung Shun, Heartbeatz, Casa Di, Versive Manhattan, Serious Beats, Da Smokestarz, among others.
In August 2012 it was announced by DJ Skee, Sirius Satellite Radio Host, that the first release from The Coronation entitled '''NO LOVE''' produced by [[Maybach Music Group|MMG's]] '''Young Shun''' was the #9 most requested song in the country.<ref>{{cite web|title=SIRIUS XM: #9 Song in the Country|url=https://twitter.com/DontHateBeHated/status/235174781102747648}}</ref> The Coronation's second release, '''Lil Kim''' produced by '''Casa Di''' gained tons of recognition as well as it was featured on both [[The Source (magazine)|The Source]] and [[The Fader]] Magazines' websites.<ref name="thesource" /><ref>{{cite web|title=FADER MAGAZINE: 3D Na'Tee Releases Lil Kim|url=http://www.thefader.com/2012/07/30/video-natee-lil-kim/#comments}}</ref> Lil Kim was a cautionary tale of a young girl with an absentee father who, because of her father's absence, unfortunately grew up and "fell in love" too fast. The song and its video (directed by Charley Mac), gained a lot of attention from tons of hiphop artist like [[Trina]], [[Missy Elliott]],<ref>{{cite web|title=WEBSTAGRAM: Trina Talks to 3D Na'Tee about 'Lil Kim|url=http://web.stagram.com/p/251601262639516075_14212753}}</ref> and Grammy Award Winning [[Chamillionaire]],<ref>{{cite web|title=BIG DOOR: Chamillionaire|url=http://www.bigdoor.com/company/press/grammy-award-winning-artist-and-bigdoor-ceo-to-speak-at-gamification-summit/}}</ref> who featured 3D Na'Tee's video on his famed social site [https://web.archive.org/web/20120802044043/http://www.chamillionaire.com/videos/play/608 www.chamillionaire.com].
==Discography==
===Albums=== *2012: ''The Coronation'' (Rerelease Plus Bonus Tracks) *2016: ''The Regime'' *2017: ''Songs That Didn't Make the Tape, Vol. 1''
===Mixtapes=== *2012: ''The Coronation'' *2010: ''Guess Who's Coming 2 Dinner'' *2008: ''Heavy Is The Head That Wears The Crown''

{{Infobox artist | bgcolour = | name = 阿鸽; Hanyu Pinyin: Ā Gē | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1948}} | birth_place = [[Liangping County|Liangshan]], [[Sichuan]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = Chinese | field = art | training = [[China Artists Association]] | movement = | works = | patrons = | influenced by = | influenced = | awards = | elected = | spouse = Xu Kuang | website = http://age.artron.net/ }} '''A Ge''' ([[Simplified Chinese]]: 阿鸽; [[Hanyu Pinyin]]: Ā Gē) (born 1948) is a [[China|Chinese]] print artist from [[Liangping County|Liangshan]] in [[Sichuan]] Province and is a member of the [[Yi people]] ethnic minority. ==Life== Per government policy towards ethnic minorities, A Ge was recruited at age twelve to attend the [[Sichuan Fine Arts Institute]] and was encouraged to create art to publicize Yi minority culture and help development.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://age.artron.net/about|title=阿鸽艺术家介绍-阿鸽官方网站-雅昌艺术家网|website=age.artron.net|access-date=2018-03-15}}</ref>
In 1964 she graduated from the national minority class at the Sichuan branch of the [[China Artists Association]].<ref>{{cite book | title=Contemporary Chinese Women Painters | author=Shi, Ling | year=1998 | publisher=Foreign Languages Press | pages=199–201 | isbn=978-7-119-00724-3}}</ref> She is married to [[Xu Kuang]].
== Career == A Ge is a Grade 1 National Artist, a member of the [[China Artists Association]] and the Chinese Engravers Association, and is chairman of the Sichuan Artists Association.<ref name="Artists">{{cite book | title=Modern Chinese Artists | author=Sullivan, Michael | year=2006 | publisher=University of California Press | page=3 | isbn=978-0-520-24449-8}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://baike.baidu.com/item/阿鸽|title=Baidu|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Her works have been collected by the [[British Museum]] in London.<ref>{{cite book | title=The Printed Image in China | author=von Spee, Clarissa | year=2010 | publisher=British Museum Press | page=171 | isbn=978-0-7141-2460-5}}</ref>
== Works == Selected works:
* 《阿鸽版画》 (''Prints of A Ge'') * 《四川少数民族画家画库·阿鸽》 (''Sichuan Minority Artists Gallery - A Ge'', 1995) * [http://age.artron.net/book_pubinfo_112017 《阿鸽作品集》](''Collection of A Ge's Artwork - A Ge, 2010 Sichuan Art Publishers'')
==References== <references/>
==External links== *[http://baike.baidu.com/view/924172.htm1.htm Baike webpage for A Ge (Chinese)] *[http://age.artron.net/ Official website for A Ge (Chinese)]
[http://age.artron.net/ {{authority control}}]
